Restigouche, 25th August, 1933.

Sir:

I beg to inform the Department that some repairs have to be performed at the Indian school this fall during the good season before the frost come. This last spring the water came in the cellar, about three inches, as long as frost been in ground, moistening the fire wood, furnace, and every articles in this cellar.

After having examined all around I came to the conclusion that the drainage is obstructed somewhere around the school. So I want to ask the permission of the Department to excavate few places to find out the trouble and to clean the drainage.

To do this work I want to ask the permission to pay small wages to the Indians making this work. This payment will give me the chance to have good men and good work, otherwise I cannot control the work of men working only for relief.

Unknowing how many days be necessary for these repairs I cannot give you the evaluation of money needed, but I can guarantee to the Department that a great discretion will be observed.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Indian Agent.
August 31, 1933.

Dear Sir,

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st instant, advising the Department of the repairs required to a drain at the Indian School at Restigouche, and in reply to advise that you may expend an amount not exceeding $50.00 to put this drain in a serviceable condition, the work to be carried out by Indians under your supervision.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

T. H. M. MacInnes,
(acting) Secretary.

Dr. A. Richard,
Indian Agent,
Restigouche, P.E.

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

As the opening of the school year is drawing quite near, I respectfully beg leave to submit the following to your kind consideration.

Since many years the Department has given $50 for the purchase of materials necessary for the teaching of sewing and knitting, which articles, when made up, are distributed to the most needy among our little ones. Last year we only...
received $35. But owing to the present financial crisis we would be fully satisfied should the Department furnish but $25 for the coming year.

We have also received $25 a month for the giving of lessons in culinary art and for the dinner of pupils going home from school. Last January that sum was reduced to $15.

Would the Department be generous enough to furnish us with the amount just mentioned $25 beginning with the month of September as we have nothing on hand for the cooking lessons which should begin with the first month of the school year. That grant will also permit us to have a little provision of food.
ahead as potatoes, butter etc. for the pupils' dinner, which will be given only in November, as usual.

Grateful witness of the never failing generosity of the Department towards our little Indians, I sincerely hope that my request will be taken in consideration. With my long experience, I can assure that the lessons of household science, and the relish of a good dinner are the chief means of attracting our little Micmacs to school.

Hoping to receive a favorable answer,

I beg to remain

D'Alt. Richard

Indian Agent.

Kind Sir

Respectfully yours,

G. M. of St. Joseph's Teacher.
Ottawa, September 5, 1933.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, and the Department has given very careful consideration to your requests. Owing to the decrease in our Appropriation, it is found that the best we can do is to authorize $15 a month from October first to March 31st for the teaching of domestic science and the supplying of midday lunch to the pupils at the Restigouche School. The sum of $26 can be allowed for the purchase of sewing material. The Indian Agent is being so informed.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Rev. Sister M. St. Joseph,
Principal,
Indian Day School,
Restigouche,
Que.
Ottawa, September 5, 1933.

Sir:

It has been decided to allow the sum of $15 a month from October first, 1933, to March 31, 1934, for the teaching of domestic science and the supplying of a midday lunch at the Restigouche Indian Day School. You may also purchase sewing material to the value of $25 for use at this school.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

A. Richard, Esq., M.D.,
Indian Agent,
Restigouche, Que.
Sir:

I beg to inform the Department that according to your letter No 26-15 of the 31st ultimo the repairs required to a drain at the Indian School at Restigouche have been performed, and the drain is in a serviceable condition.

After having took the advice of the man who built this drain and the advice of some others I have started the work and found the right place at once where it was block. Having the good men very much in need of clothing this work was well made and it is of my opinion that this drain will stand for some while yet. But to prevent the floor of cellar from wet it would be necessary to take off all the cement floor and place drain pipes all around and in the center of cellar and build a new cement floor.

Please find enclosed the return of labour for this done, and for which work have been already paid.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dr. Richard,
St. Anne De Restigouche.

Dear Sir:

As requested by you, we examined the furnace in the school at St. Anne De Restigouche, and find same in very bad condition. The top section of firepot is cracked on both sides, and opened up about ½ inch.

This section, together with the mason and tinsmith work, and perhaps other parts we would find that needed to be renewed, would cost nearly the price of a new furnace.

We would therefore recommend a new furnace with a galvanized iron casing instead of brick, as it is less expensive to repair furnace at any time with the galvanized casing.

As you only asked for a price on repairing furnace, we are quoting you a price on temporary repair to furnace that would last the winter, and some new pipe that is needed, --a price of Fifteen Dollars—$15.00.

Trusting this is the information you require, we are

Yours very truly,

Bradley & Walsh.

Per... A. Bradley

Sir:

I beg to include two reports regarding the furnace of Indian School. One report sent to me not long ago by Government Inspector for public buildings shows that the furnace of our Indian School needs good repair. The second report of the plumbing man says the furnace is done but can be repaired for this next winter.

Rostigouche May 21, 1884

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Kind Sir,

Being desirous of encouraging our little Indians at the end of the school year to refer to the Department for a few dollars to buy some prizes, we generally receive twenty dollars every year except last year.

Would it be unkind to give the said amount, whatever your generosity inclines, even a small reward at least, for those who attended more regularly would stimulate their good will for next year, and will be heard with warm thanks from those who recognize your invaluable help.

Sincerely yours,

Sr. M. of St. Joseph.
Prestigouche, May 21, 1894

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Kind Sir,

I should be sorry to appear importunate, but necessity obliges me to apply once more to the generosity of the Department.

The floors of three apartments of our school need to be done over; one class-room, the kitchen and serving rooms, which have not been painted since two years. We would also ask some varnish for the pupils' desks. I think that the sum of eight dollars will be sufficient.

Should the Department feel willing to allow us that small amount we will be very grateful.

Sincerely Yours,

[Signature]

Restigouche, 22nd June, 1934.

Sir:-

I beg to report to the Department that our Indian Day School has a very bad roof, leaking badly, and when the wind blows hard the shingles are flying everywhere. As this school has a large roof I would like to know if this work have to be done by days work, or by tenders.

Also it is at the knowledge of the Department that the furnace at this same school have been condemned last summer by the inspector of public buildings, but with good repairs it could past the winter. Now this furnace is done and school needs a new one. I suppose also I have to ask for tenders, but Sisters want furnace for coal instead of wood as before. Please advise me what to do and how to proceed.

The report of the plumber, Bradly and Walsh, Campbellton, N.B. is at your office since last summer.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa. Ont.
Ottawa, June 29, 1934.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant, with reference to the roof and furnace at the Restigouche Indian Day School.

An officer of the Department intends to visit Restigouche in the near future, and he is being instructed to ascertain exactly what repairs are required. When his report is received, the matter will have further consideration. I may say that, as our Appropriation is limited, it will not be possible to expend any large sum of money at the Restigouche Indian Day School this year.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Dr. Arthur Richard,
Indian Agent,

Ottawa, August 29, 1934.

Sir:

In further reference to your letter of June 22nd, last, reporting on the condition of the roof of the Restigouche Indian Day School, I would request that you submit a report, stating the cost involved. You should advise the Department, also, if you could not arrange to have the work carried out by Indian labour, provided you were given authority to purchase any materials, such as shingles and nails that may be required.

Regarding the request for a new furnace, the Department has no particulars as to the type, heating capacity and the cost of the furnace and installing same. Our funds this year are so limited that unless a new furnace is absolutely urgent we would not be prepared to authorize the expenditure required. When we have your estimate of the cost involved in the supplying and installing of a new furnace, further consideration will be given, and you will be advised.

Your obedient servant,

Restigouche, 5th September, 1934.

Sir:

In reply to your letter No 26-1-5 of the 29th ultimo with the reference to the condition of the roof of the Restigouche Indian Day School, I beg to say I sent a man again yesterday to examine this roof and to see if it was possible to repair only the places leaking. This man reported to me the shingles were all rotten all over the roof. This roof will take around 22 thousands of shingles, and with the nails, boards to cover the top of roof and for the scaffoldings, to take off the old shingles and the labour for the whole work will come for all the repair to amount of about $140.00.

It is very hard to give the right amount for such a repair, but the Department can be sure I will look well after the work and if some money can be save, I will do it. I can easy get good men to have the work carried out by Indian labour.

If it is possible for the Department to make this urgent repair at once, I would be please to receive your cheque for the payment of those Indians asking for money after few days work.

Restigouche, May 20th 1935

Report of the requirements of the Indian Reserve at Restigouche, supplied by the missionary of the locality.

1st - Our school is no longer sufficient to contain the pupils of school age. It will be necessary to have two new class rooms in the fall. It may be possible to rent two classes in the white school adjoining the sisters' convent next autumn.

2nd - On such a large reserve as Restigouche, in proximity of Campbellton, on account of the easy access by water and land to the reserve, especially during this time of unemployment and forced inactivity, it is urgent to have a strong local police force.

That police would be useful to watch the attendance at school and overcome the insubordination of the strong heads who are conspiring. For a year past, it is the charity of the missionary that prevented riots among certain hasty individuals who were drawn to extremes.

I spent more than $100. To keep peace among your Indians. Among those who could fill the position of constable there are James Savigne, if he is not too old, and George Isaac, and Albert Martin.

3rd - The Cemetery

It would be necessary to renew the fence posts for the wire fence and raise the upper part by buying earth instead of buying a new piece of ground.

I hope gentlemen that you will consider these requests carefully and that you will give me a favorable reply soon.
and that we will have a police officer,
two new class rooms in the fall and
that the question of the cemetery will
be finally settled.

Respectfully yours,

During my recent visit to the Restigouche agency the agent Dr. Richard requested me to make inquiry into the question of insufficient school accommodation.

The present school has accommodation for 35 children whereas there are 120 children of school age on the reserve. Many of the desks are of such small size as to cramp the older children into positions which is very detrimental to their health, especially as many of them are consumptive.

A new building for the reception of no less than 60 older children is a prime necessity on this reserve, and I would recommend that provision be made in next year's estimates for the construction of a modern school house separate to but in the vicinity of the present school building.

The present building does not permit of it being enlarged, and the agent should be authorised to have the outside steps repaired, which are in a dangerous and dilapidated condition, and to see that the roof around one of the disused chimneys, which is in a leaky condition should also be re-shingled and the chimney removed.

Dear Sir,

As negotiations are being made to obtain from the Department of Indian Affairs an enlargement of our school house to cater with a sanatorium for the Indians of this reserve, I beg to take advantage of the occasion to attract the Department's notice on the following:

Since the Sisters have the direction of this Indian school no claim has been made concerning the Indian teachers' dwelling, this being gratuitously provided for by the Reverend Capuchin Fathers. The said convent having undergone severe deterioration, very costly improvements are required, the charges of which neither the Reverend Fathers nor the Sisters can afford to assume. Consequently, I deem the Department will kindly do its utmost to be of some help to us in the present occurrence and I very respectfully beg that in the sketches defining the new buildings, rooms be put aside for the teachers' and nurses' accommodations.

I trust the Department will kindly take this request in efficient consideration and comply with it as best it can.

In this hope and thanking you sincerely for past favors I remain respectfully and gratefully yours,

Honourable Gentlemen,

Knowing that you take interest in whatever concerns our Indian pupils' welfare and improvement, we, by the present respectfully and earnestly request:

1. For our Indian girls, the favour of a new sewing machine, which we cannot do without in teaching them how to make up their own clothes.

The one we had so far has been repaired over and over, and is now completely out of use and unfit to be repaired.

2. For our pupils' use, a supply of toilet paper; the plumber having forbidden the use of any other kind as it might block up the pipe and injure the apparatus.

3. A certain number of schoolbags.
which are badly needed, as the pupils often lose their school objects and when they go out they are in the same condition.

We feel sure that you will kindly answer our needs and grant what we ask from your benevolent people.

The education at our Indian school always impresses chief justice to the admirable staff of Indians officers who stand so generously with them.

Please agree our respectful wishes and thankful regards for past favors.

Resignedly,

Poveshuken.

Minutes of the Council meeting held in the Council Hall of Restigouche Reserve the 1st of February.

Moved by Chief Frank Isaac, seconded by all the Councillors that the Department persists to come in help to our reserve in giving us new building with two more class rooms and one floor with rooms to keep with nurse our sick Indians with T.B. to prevent the contagion to others.

The second resolution is to ask again to the Department for new class rooms having too many children for the class rooms we have now. Form No. 518
I visited the RESTIGOUCHE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL on August 15th, last, in company with the Indian Agent, Dr. Richard; Rev. Father Placide, the Parish Priest; and the Sister Superior of the School.

The school building and a separate residence, attached by a covered passage, are located on property owned by the Capucins. There are three small classrooms in the school building - two on the ground floor and one on the floor above, at the rear of the building. There is also a room fitted up with a stove, for domestic science purposes. The classrooms are small and inadequate to provide accommodation for the Indian children of school age on the reserve. The residence of the Sisters is in very poor condition. The drainage from the basement of both the school and the residence is inadequate. Owing to the nature of the ground, water is continually seeping in. These are both frame buildings and, while not the property of the Department, yet considerable expense has been incurred from time to time, in repairs. It will be necessary in the very near future to carry out extensive repairs and alterations in both buildings, or they should be demolished and a new combined school and teacher's residence erected containing two classrooms, each for 36 children, and living accommodation for three or four Sisters, with a room for a chapel. This would meet the needs for this part of the reserve. The lot on which these buildings are erected comprises a small area. There is very little space for playgrounds.

This brings up the matter of providing adequate school accommodation for the children of this large reserve. There are approximately 140 to 150 children of school age, nearly half of whom live at too great a distance to attend the present school. These children could be better served by the erection of a school, with two classrooms and living accommodation for two teachers, at a central locality on the west end of the reserve.

Funds are provided under the Special Building Programme this year to erect a two-roomed school with teacher's living quarters. I would suggest that, if the work is proceeded with, this building be erected on a site central to meet the needs of the Indian children at the west end of the reserve. No site has been selected, but this could be, no doubt, arranged by the local Agent. There would likely be objection, on the part of the church authorities, to having a school erected on the west end of the reserve, as it would be a considerable distance from the present church property. If this school is erected, I would suggest that lay teachers be employed. I was not favourably impressed with the teaching Order who are conducting the three classrooms in the present school building, near the church.

Memorandum:

Mr. Miller.

RE: INSPECTION OF DAY SCHOOLS AT RESTIGOUCHE AND CAUGHNAWAGA, QUEBEC.

The present Day School at Restigouche, Que., consists of two buildings both being two storey frame construction.

The school building has three classrooms, a kitchen and a small general purpose room. The three classrooms are very small and inadequate for the number of students enrolled. The kitchen room has been used for both the preparation and serving of meals and is entirely too small for such use. The sewing room is satisfactory only for small classes. This building is in fair condition and can be used in connection with any new buildings with a few minor repairs to the roof and ceilings.

The second building, used as a residence for the teachers, is in a very dilapidated condition and would be best removed.

In connection with these two buildings is a very dilapidated frame building which is used as a school for the French children in the village.

The removal of these last two buildings would provide a suitable site for a new classroom unit, large enough to accommodate 105 to 120 students.

If a new school unit comprising three classrooms, a partial basement for the heating system and fuel storage, and additional rooms in the rear for vocational classes is erected then the present school building could be used for a teachers' residence and for the kitchen and dining room for teachers and students.

In consideration of the condition of the buildings and the requirements for the day school it would be advisable to remove the existing French School and the teachers' residence buildings, erect a new three classroom school on the site of the removed buildings and remodel the existing school house to provide a residence for the teachers and kitchen and dining facilities for the teachers and students.

The United Church Day School at Caughnawaga, Que., at present is comprised of a one room school building. In providing an addition to this school of one classroom and living quarters for two teachers two courses are possible. 1st. A direct addition to the northern end of the existing building and 2nd. a separate building in the rear of the present building.
The Welfare and Training Division are considering the site situation at this school and will advise as to which course should be followed.

Mr R. A. Hoey, Supt, of Welfare and Training,

Dear Mr Hoey,

Mr Phelan and the architect have been most welcomed here last week. We regret though, they could not stay with us any longer, for many questions about the new building are not definitely settled.

I respectfully beg to be allowed a few questions and suggestions.... After many deliberations about the lodging of the sisters, it was decided that the old Indian Day School should be our residence. Will the Department have the repairs of same done at the same time the new school be built? The roof, the foundation, and a few windows require particular attention. Inside, we expect that the partitions be modified so as to facilitate the observances.

As the actual Indian School cannot supply us with bed-rooms, I shall respectfully ask that provisions be made on the new plan to provide the attic with seven bed-rooms for the sisters affected to the service of the Indians:

1o- The Principal and teacher of Domestic Science
2o- Four teachers
3o- One lay sister, cook for the sisters
4o- One lay sister, cook for the Indian children.
I would suggest also that an office or room for the Principal, nearby the school rooms would be very advantageous.

As Mr Phelan suggested that we should adopt the rotative system in our new school, we shall be pleased to comply with his wishes; but let us together foresee the means to facilitate the rotation. So, would it be possible to have sliding or swinging doors between two classes, so as to transmute them into a main room when necessary?

What would you think of the idea of giving up serving mid-day meal with the first of June and allow us to get material from Atlantic Trading Co., for the approximate amount spent monthly for food, to begin modifying two of the upper rooms. Then we can move a part of our furniture therein and have our residence torn down, so that the ground be ready when you begin building the new school.

You would appreciate, I am sure, knowing that if you allow us a certain amount to be spent, let us say $400.00, for the inside repairs and modifications, we shall save money for you; because we often obtain favors as to the price of material or workmanship owing to our well-known poverty; whilst when people know that it is to be paid by the Government they charge full cost.

Pardon me for keeping you so long reading my requests. In the meantime, I am fully confident that you will approve them as they are but fair, and in accordance with the promises made by different officials sent here those last years.

With sentiments of esteem and sincerest best wishes

I remain,

Very gratefully yours,

Sister M. of St Leo, Principal.

I am not in a position to state just why the Department has not proceeded with the construction of this building. Dear Doctor,

I arrived at Campbellton this A.M. and proceeded to the Reserve accompanied by Constable Murphy, R.C.M.P., where we met Dr. Richard, (Indian Agent). Excavating for the new school has started today, and I found Mr. Ross, of the Engineering Dept., in charge. The work is being done by Indians, who receive 25¢ per hour and are pleased to be employed.

Mr. Ross states that he is faced with difficulty because the plan provides for a cellar ten feet deep, of which seven or eight feet must be below the surface of the ground, whereas rock is met at four feet or a little less below the surface. Furthermore, the drain is on the surface of the rock for the cellar. He will write his superiors about this matter and submit his report to them, as to how the problem might be solved. He desired however to let us know the situation, so that we would understand the possibility of changes, to fit the building to the site.

Mr. Ross is negotiating for a white carpenter foreman; it is understood that no qualified Indian is available.

I visited the Principal and teacher's residence at the request of Sister Mary of Ste. Leo. There I met in addition to the principal and her assistant two sisters from Rimouski, who had come to enquire about the School, representing the Provincial Head of the order. The plans provided for three class rooms instead of four. They understood from Mr. Maclean when he visited in May that four would be provided. They pointed out that the three rooms are designed to accommodate 100 pupils whereas there are actually 130, exclusive of the number of young children coming up. They suggested that the necessary additional class room be substituted for the boys' work room as shown on the plan, as the class room is the more essential. They urgently request that the stair plan be changed so that the pupils may enter the room directly for class purposes, instead of through the sewing room, as they would do if the present plans which have been in mind were a work shop are carried out.

They also state that further repairs are needed in the old building before it can be used as a residence, as there is water in the basement. This is additional to repairs authorized in Mr. Hoey's letter of May 21st last, which were for the upstairs.

They also ask for the connecting passage between the residence and the school, such as was formerly provided.

To the best of my observation and judgment, their requests are reasonable and well founded, particularly regarding the additional class room, this would regard immediate attention at Ottawa, as it is understood that the purchasing agent is proceeding with the purchase of the materials, which may have to be varied. I have been desired to bring all these matters to your attention forthwith, for consideration by yourself and the various officials concerned in our own and Engineering Branch.

Yours Very Truly,

Sgd. T.R.L. MacInnes.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter dated the 20th of October from Mr. T.R.L. MacInnes, Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, with reference to his recent visit to the Restigouche Indian Day School. Apparently the Sister Superior requested some changes in the plans prepared for the new school.

The plans provide for three classrooms, sewing room and workshop. If any changes were made in the plans at the present time it would probably delay construction to such an extent that nothing could be done this fall. The building will be constructed in such a way that an addition can be added at any time and, in the meantime, if a fourth class room is absolutely necessary, the room intended for a workshop can be used as a class room. However, the Department considers that by rotating classes there is no reason why three class rooms should not be sufficient; in addition, sewing room and workshop were provided in order that adequate facilities would be available for giving to the pupils practical instruction that should be useful to them in their future life.

With the above in mind, the Department is not prepared to make any changes in the present plans and it is hoped that construction of the building will proceed as quickly as possible.

Memorandum

Mr. Mills

Re - Hours of Work on Day School and Teacher's Residence, Restigouche Indian Reserve, Quebec.

In view of representations made to the Department that in order to expedite the above work and to have exterior work sufficiently advanced so that the whole work will not have to be closed down due to winter conditions, a longer working day should be adopted, the Minister of Labour has approved the waiving of the provisions of the Fair Wages and Hours of Labour Act of 1935 relative to working hours on this project and has approved allowing working hours up to a maximum of 10 hours per day.

Whether or not our Engineer will be able to work 10 hours a day will of course depend upon the amount of daylight available and if only 9 hours is possible, this will of course be satisfactory.

The above ruling applies to Saturdays also. Kindly note, however, that no work is to be done on Sundays.

Will you kindly wire Mr. Ross to this effect so that the longer day can be started on Monday.

Director.

Dear Sir:

I beg to inform the Department that the Indian Day School be ready to open the classes next month in the new building. The children are running in the road since the end of last June. This reopening of classes will be a great thing for those young pupils.

Now I would like to know if it would be possible for the Department to do something again this year as last year for food at school. This extra meal given last year gave so good results regarding the health of them assisting regularly, that I will be very pleased if food could be given again this winter.

As the new school building is not arranged to make any cooking, either having no other building around to install a stove and cook the food, I would suggest, and it is the opinion of the Principal of the school, that a cold meal could be served to the children. Cod Liver Oil and milk with bead and butter, peanut butter, preserves, or anything else ordered by Department.

This our suggestion but I will be very glad to receive from the Department the orders for what you believe is the best, if anything can be done.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Re - Restigouche Indian Day School, Quebec.

Our Chief Engineer advises that the construction of the above school was completed on February 1st, the expenditure to date being slightly less than $9,250.

Due to winter conditions, it was possible to give the outside of the building, with the exception of the roof, only one coat of paint. However, paint was left in storage at the site for two coats for the exterior of the building, including the roof.

The outside concrete steps leading to the basement were damaged by frost during a severe cold spell and will need to be replaced. The estimated cost of these two small items of work is as follows:

Labour for painting .....$150.
Replacement of steps ..... 25.

It is suggested that your Indian Agent should undertake this work early in the Spring.

Our Engineer on this work recommends that the following extras be supplied for the School and which were not provided for in the specifications:

3 storm doors for the first floor classrooms.
2 sets of steps to the terrace around the building.
A platform at each of the four outside doors.
The cost of these extra items is estimated at $75.00, making a total of $250.00 for painting, steps and extras. This amount together with that of $9,250 expended to date would give a total cost of $9,500 for the building.

As you are aware, calls for tenders on this building were issued and after a long delay, the only tender received amounted to $12,700. This tender, which covered the same plans and specifications under which the building was constructed by day labour, was not accepted and, while day labour work was largely undertaken under winter conditions, a substantial saving was effected.

By this memorandum a formal transfer of the completed building is being made to your Branch.

Attached herewith for your files is a set of five photographs showing exterior and interior views of the completed building.

Director.
Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

I have recently received the following vouchers: No. 304 for $32.40, milk supplied to children at Restigouche School during February; No. 308 for $72.81, food for midday meal at Restigouche School during February; No. 342 for $66.56, midday meal supplies during March.

As the expenditure has been incurred and the supplies delivered there is no other action the Department can take but to pay the account. However, I was surprised that you allowed such heavy expenditure as this was not authorized in official letter of January 17. In that letter you were advised that the cost each month must not exceed the amount allowed last year and at that time we were only allowing an amount of $20.00 a month toward the cost of midday meal supplies.

In purchasing material for midday meals it is not expected that a full course meal will be served as this involves not only heavy expense but means a great deal of work in preparing same and cleaning up afterwards.

It is only intended that light refreshments should be served such as soup or a hot drink and biscuits.

There should be sufficient supplies on hand to provide a midday lunch for the month of April but in any case the expenditure for midday meal supplies for the

Extract from Inspector Thibeault's report of March 31, 1938:

"The new school house is a very good looking building inside, and with a finishing coat of paint on the outside, it will have a better appearance.

"A terrace surrounds this new building and porches and steps will have to be built - if not already provided for in the specifications of construction. The slanting face of the terrace should be protected by strips of sod or turf to prevent erosion. Grass seed should be sowed on top of the terrace.

"In order to keep the grounds clean and to prevent cattle from running in, a fence should be erected at back of grounds and partly on one side so as to enclose the whole thing. About four hundred feet of fence would be required."

Dear Sir:

Restigouche, April 5th, 1938.

Dear Sir:

En réponse à votre lettre du 5 de ce mois je dois vous dire que ma surprise a été bien grande d'apprendre le désaveu des dépenses encourues pour le repas du midi donné aux enfants Indiens,

Je dois dire sincèrement que les Institutrices et moi avons agi sur l'interprétation de votre lettre du 17 Janvier, 1938, en nous basant que les dépenses ne dépasseraient pas celles de l'an dernier. Or l'an dernier les dépenses ont été à peu près les mêmes que celles de cette année. Les groceries cette année étant plus chères nous en avons donné beaucoup moins que l'an dernier, mais le compte est aussi élevé parce que le nombre de l'assistance en classe est plus élevé que l'an dernier. Il ya deux ans et plus nous n'avions que $20.00 par mois pour un petit repas aux enfants éloignés, à peu près une dizaine, les autres ne venaient pas.

Après avoir commis cette erreur de dépenses trop fortes en février j'aurais beaucoup mieux aimé en avoir été averti immédiatement à mon premier compte. Mais puisque le coup est fait et que le Département est assez bon de payer ces comptes, je dois vous avertir qu'en recevant votre lettre hier je suis allé au magasin et ai fait fermer ce compte, alors dans une journée ou deux il n'y aura plus de repas. Le montant de $10.00 alloué pour le mois d'avril était déjà dépensé quand votre lettre est arrivée.

Les comptes de lait et de groceries vous parviendront sous peu.

Votre obéissant serviteur,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 5th instant I may say that I was greatly surprised to learn that the Department disapproved of the expense incurred for the meals given to the Indian children every noon.

I must say that the teachers and myself acted in good faith according to our interpretation of your letter of January 17th, 1936, basing ourselves on the fact that expenses should not be higher than they were last year. Now, last year's expenditures are about the same as this year's. The price of groceries having gone up this year, we gave the children much less than last year but the account is no smaller due to the fact that there are more children attending school than there were last year. Two years ago and more, we had only $20.00 per month to give a very frugal meal to the children who live far from the school, there were about ten of them, and the others did not come.

After having made the mistake of spending too much in February, I would have preferred being advised of the fact immediately after I sent in my first account, but since the thing is done and the Department was kind enough to pay these accounts, I beg to advise you that, upon receipt of your letter yesterday, I went to the store and closed this account so that in a day or two no more meals will be given. The amount of $10.00 allowed for the month of April had already been spent when your letter arrived.

You will receive shortly the accounts for milk and groceries.

Yours truly,

(sgd) D. Arthur Richard

Dear Mr. Henry,

While pending the final decision, it would be very convenient and protect the whole building from being damaged. The ladies, having a covered place where they can put the wet oil tins, but the difference in cleaning the floors will be reduced, and the terrace will retain its proper appearance.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter dated April 14 from Sister Mary of St. Leo with reference to placing porches and double doors on the new Restigouche School.

While this would no doubt be a convenience at the same time I must point out that we have no funds specially provided in our current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements to this building.

In official letter of the 8th instant you were requested to let me have an estimate of the cost of the labour for painting the Restigouche School. When we have this work completed we will again consider the request of the Principal for porches, etc., but, as pointed out in the first paragraph of this letter, it is very doubtful if we can provide funds for the purpose.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 8th instant regarding the paint in storage at the new School for two coats for the exterior of the building, I beg to inform the Department there is no paint for the outside painting. The paint in storage is as follow:

- Roofing - Red shingle paint, 20 gallons
- Window frame - White 8 "
- Floor - Red varnish stain 5 2"
- Halls (inside) Ivory paint, 3 "

This is all the paint found at School from last fall, no paint for outside walls.

There is also a high earth work all around the school which have to be finished, having hauled the last earth late in fall and mixed with snow, some more earth be needed to finish it well. By the Report of Mr Inspector J. Thibault some grass should be placed to cover this kind of clay ground. This have to be completed with more earth at some places for about six inches.

It is of my opinion the work labour can be done with the Indians, it is a kind of rough work which don't take specialist for to do it. This work will come to the cost of about $75.00 XXX for the paint.

Memorandum:

MR. HARDIE

Re: Restigouche Indian Day School

In your memorandum of February 16 in connection with the above school you wrote, in part, as follows:

"Paint was left in storage at the site for two coats for the exterior of the building including the roof."

Recently we wrote the Indian Agent with a view to arranging for the painting and I am today in receipt of the following reply:

"I beg to inform the Department there is no paint for the outside painting. The paint in storage is as follows:

Roofing - Red shingle paint 20 gallons
Window frame - white 3 "
Floor - red varnish stain 3 "
Walls (inside) ivory paint 3 "

I would appreciate your advising the exact quantities of paint which you stated in your memorandum of February 16 had been left at the school. Director.
Restigouche, April 22nd, 1938.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 8th instant regarding the fence at Indian School at the back of the grounds, I beg to inform the Department that there is practically no fence at all. Some old wires are down on ground, many old pickets broken and the others are no good. In summer time the cattles go in the school yard, cannot cultivate without to be destroyed and eaten by cattles. With good fence a good recreation yard, or garden to be made by children, this can be organized easy in making nice yard.

The fence in front of the old school have to be removed, the new school taking larger ground, from this fence going to back line, and fix the back line all together make about 400 ft, about 350 feet of new fence. To save expenses we can make this back fence with wood. I have figured that pickets and boards will cost about $40.00, and the labour to about $60.00 to 75.00. The labour, the time to make the fence depends on the time to fix up the pickets, if not too much rocks.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I beg to inform the Department that last Wednesday, the 22nd instant, with a rain storm and a strong gale, a large tree in the school yard close the fence fell down deracinated across the school fence and in the garden of the neighbour breaking also his fence.

This old poplar was more than half rotten and I could not have people to take it away for fire wood. So being across a little road going to few Indian houses I been in the obligation to take men and horses to cut and haul it away. The stump was so big and so heavy that I used dynamite to have it out the deep and large hole. In dynamiting a stone broke a large glass in the neighbour's door. After this the men fixed the fence and leveled the ground, the yard is clean and in good condition. There is still an other old tree about in the same condition, but if can stand the summer I expect to take it down next winter.

I have done the best for less expenses and I expect the Department will approve the accounts included.

Restigouche, September 9th, 1935.

Dear Sir:

It is at the knowledge of the Department since last winter and this last spring that the work around the Indian Day school was not completed. The embankment around the building having been made last winter with blocks of frozen ground came down this spring over one foot by places after the thaw was done. Having no foundation, the building is on posts, the wind runs free under the floor of the three class-rooms making very cold for the teacher and the pupils.

Also at the three doors of the classes there are no boards or platform for the pupils to pass on before go in the school taking in all the mud around their shoes.

I suppose Mr Inspector J. Thibault took this matter before you and have explained the situation.

I cannot tell you exactly the cost of this work to level the embankment, to build platform and good stormy doors, but I believe this will be around $125.00. I promise to the Department to make this work as cheap as possible. If this cannot be done it is of my opinion that the Department will have to pay more for the Janitor to make fire all day and all night to prevent the frost in the toilet rooms and also to purchase double more firewood. Please send the invoice for labour.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Restigouche, September 10th, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I beg to ask the Department if there is money available for the pupils at the school to give a lunch every day as years before.

We used to have an average of 40 pupils taking the lunch every day at the school from November to April; the children living too far from the school to go home on account of bad weather or very cold days. They bring a crust of bread and eat it with cold water. We cannot give good meal as before having no local to serve it and no kitchen to cook the meal.

The Sister Superior told me she can give the meal every day for 0.06 per day making $64.00 per month. If the Department desires to give milk every day and to every child this will take about 7 gallons of milk per day at 0.39 per gallon for the average assistance of 120 pupils on the list.

I would be very pleased if the Department could do something for those young children coming to school. The food given in the past to them at the school has given so good result that I recommend again for this year that the Department make the best to help those children.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir,

Report re Restigouche Agency.

The outside painting of the school house is now completed and the work was well done.

Upon my first inspection in March, 1938, of this Agency, I had suggested building porches and steps for each classroom entrance as well as for the main entrance, but so far nothing was done. The terrace around the building is in bad shape. The water from the roof all around the building falls on this terrace and has soaked in near the foundation. If the water remains under the building, it will surely cause damage to the floors if nothing is done to remedy this situation. The centre of the building only has cement foundation and cellar which is for the furnace. The rest of the building is on posts and single boarded all around with discolored against the boards, forming a terrace about three feet high and five to six feet wide. I could find no ventilation whatever going under the building and, therefore, the water going under the building should be prevented.

A roofed verandah in front with a shorter one for entrance of pupils at the back of the building would help quite a bit in stopping the water gathering under the building. This verandah with steps to the bottom of the terrace could be useful for the pupils on rainy days and would help to keep the classroom cleaner as now the children are entering the school room directly from outside and mud and snow are carted in on their shoes. As for the other part of the terrace, it should be so changed as to let the water run away from the building.

Six double desks for juniors, seven to eight years of age, are needed at once.

I was sorry to hear that the mid-day lunch to children living far from school had been cancelled. The milk distribution should also be kept up.

Photographs will help to explain more clearly regarding the terrace and verandah suggested in above report. I shall take this matter up when I return.

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Restigouche, September 20th, 1938.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 14th instant regarding the lunch for the children of the Restigouche Indian Day School, I beg to inform the Department that the only thing we can do is a cold lunch as last year. An average of 40 pupils are taking the dinner at the school from November to April, when a regular meal is not allowed to all the children. 40 lunches per day 20 days of school make $64.00 per month. It will be better to start from October 15 to April 15.

There is no kitchen in the present Restigouche School. There are three class rooms on the first floor, and on the second floor is a sewing room and a woodwork room, not one of them is accommodated for the installation of kitchen stove to learn cookery to the Indian girls. The Teacher's cookery is in another building, is too small to have something cooked for children.

We have this year 140 children listed giving an average of 120 every day at the school.

Your obedient servant,

The Department will appreciate any suggestion you may have as to how this might be improved at any time through the winter.

There is not much that can be done immediately in the way of segregation of tuberculous Indians at your Agency and until the new sanatorium opens at Mont Joli, it is advisable that the children have as good food as the school organization can reasonably provide them with.

Yours truly,

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Restigouche, November 25th, 1932.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 21st instant regarding the washing of the class rooms at the Restigouche Indian Day School, I beg to inform the Department The Principal of the school and I we did not figure that kind of work goes with the Janitor work. Since this Janitor, Peter Sewell started his duty on the 15th of October he was working at the school every day and all along the days work on the repairs at the school, because many little things were neglected last winter. When we figure the time spent at the school for the Janitor we did not mark the washing of the class rooms, there are so many little jobs around the school and inside that the salary comes small. Peter Sewell is willing to look after the washing in future on the condition he don't pay for the one done in October by women.

This is the first time this work is refused for payment, last year the Department paid for the washing to women. Please pay this last one and we will try to manage in future.

Your obedient servant,

Gentlemen,

I respectfully beg leave to request presently that the Honourable Staff of your Department Branch oblige our Community with a written statement, acknowledging that the building - old Indian school made over - used now for teachers' Residence belongs entirely to your Department, whose right alone it is to affect any changes, and from whom are to be claimed all repairs whatever concerning the said building.

I'm sure you will readily comply with this request, considering that the Principal of Restigouche Indian School is liable to change at any time and so with the Indian Agent on the Reserve; at such events, reference to a written statement on the matter should clearly settle any trouble that could arise concerning the ownership of said building.

Trusting that you will kindly grant me a favourable reply, at your earliest convenience.

I remain,

Yours Respectfully

Sister M. of St. Leo, Principal

Dear Sister:

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant the Department considers that both the school and teachers' residence at Restigouche Reserve are our property.

Unauthorized repairs to these buildings cannot be paid for but whenever repairs are required the matter should be brought to the attention of the Indian Agent who will write to the Department. Such requests will receive careful consideration and if the repairs are considered necessary, and funds are available, the necessary authority will then be given.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

Restigouche, March 9th, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report to the Department concerning the conditions of the Restigouche Reserve for the months of January and February that situation is not the most favourable. The temperature having been very bad brought all the attendants in sickness and poverty.

The attendance to school was not much good for while but now is coming better. The weather was so stormy and cold that the distant pupils could not come to school but in return the teachers could give them more lunch and so to keep them in better health.

Hoping the hot spring weather will come soon in order to chase the disease, I remain.

Dr. Art. Richard.

Dear Mrs. Grey:

Having engaged a fourth teacher for the Boys' Senior Class, I thought of giving you some information regarding the school furniture, of which we will stand in need in September. To simplify the explanations, I am enclosing designs of the necessary equipment:

1. Teacher's desk.
2. Teacher's chair.
3. 20 pupils' desk-chairs, which could be removed more easily than desks.
4. Blackboard, 20 ft. in length.
5. Wood work Apprentice benches. A large wood work bench will also be needed for the centre of the class, but that one could be made here.
Allow me, dear Sir, to state that I already asked the Department to have the Baby Class supplied with six pupils' desks No. 6, and, due to my own forgetfulness in mentioning that these desk and seats were double, we are yet short of six similar ones, in order to place forty pupils in that class. Just now, we are using a long rough bench borrowed from a neighbor. We could wait for them, till the Department sends the equipments for the Manual Training Class.

If you judge it wise, dear Mr. Roy, to modify any of my suggestions, I accept them in advance, as I know they will contribute to improve our situation, having years of experience in such organizations.

Remain

Dear Sir,

Truly yours,

Mrs. R. A. Roy

As the number of pupils staying for midday lunches increases daily, I make it my duty to respectfully ask the Department to kindly permit me to spend the same amount of $64.80 monthly to cover the expenses of midday meals served at the Estigouche Indian Day School. This amount would not be sufficient to answer to our needs during the coldest months, but I generally store up cases of canned goods during the early months, which we serve.
only when the number of pupils rises from 55 to 60. This foreseeing permits me to provide them a fairly good midday meal.

At present, I observe that most of the children remaining here for dinner, bring only bread and molasses. At first, I thought they wanted to draw my pity by bringing such a scanty quantity; but the fact that they persist in their small diet convinces me that necessity forces them to such short allowance.

Dear Mr. Roy:

I hereby respectfully give you notice that the present sewing room of the Restigouche Indian Day School being too small to employ twenty girls at sewing and loom weaving; the said apartment is left vacant.

I confidently trust that if the honorable Board of Indian Affairs was informed of the fact, that you would approve my suggestion in organizing a kitchen in its place, where cooking lessons and mid-day meals be prepared. For such organization a small coal oil or wood cooking stove would be
the only apparatus to be renewed.

I am ever ready to approve your final decision.

I beg to offer you my sincere feelings of gratitude for past favors, as also my anticipated thanks for the present one.

Very truly yours,

December 15, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 1st instant with reference to the request of the principal of the Restigouche Indian day school for a new oil stove in order to permit teaching of domestic science.

Due to present conditions funds at our disposal are quite limited and consequently it is not possible to consider new expenditures. Besides the use of an oil stove in the Restigouche school would constitute a fire hazard.

The Department feels that the Reverend Sisters wish to co-operate with us and it is difficult to understand why the room used for sewing is considered too small. Possibly all the girls learning sewing cannot be accommodated in the room at the same time but there would appear to be no reason why the sewing class could not be taken in groups.

The teachers' residence is comparatively close to the school and it should be possible to have the girls go into the kitchen of this residence in groups and receive instruction in the culinary arts.

With reference to your letter of the 9th instant if you consider a storm door absolutely necessary you may incur an expenditure of $8.50 in installing it.

Yours truly,

Dr. A. Richard,
Indian Agent,
Restigouche, Que.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Restigouche, August 2nd, 1940.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 30th ultimo regarding the cost of cleaning and scrubbing at the Restigouche Indian Day School, I beg to inform the Department I did not request the permission for this expenditure because since 12 years it is the practice to clean the school at the end of every year like we done this year without special authority except for special materials if needed.

It is at the knowledge of the Department that the caretaker comes in duty on the 1st of October till the 1st of May, so this Janitor was not on duty to make this cleaning and scrubbing. This Janitor, Peter Sewell, took sick this spring and his son finished the month of May, and died two weeks ago. Anyhow a man of this kind is not the right person to make a good general cleaning of a house, specially a large building like this Indian school.

With those explanations I am returning the vouchers and the receipts hoping this will be approved. In saving 3 months of salary to the Janitor with the profit this cleaning bill can be paid.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Sir;-

At the re-opening of the school year, I regret to have, especially at such a critical period, to expose to the Honourable Staff of Indian Affairs a defect in the floor, of the Restigouche Indian Day School which makes the teachers suffer from constant cold feet during the winter season.

For this reason, I humbly ask the Department if it would not be possible to have a platform made for the three teacher's desks on the first floor, of about 9 inches high. The said work has been examined by a carpenter of this Reserve and he claims to be able to furnish wood, nails, paint, and do the work for $45.00.

The Agent being absent he will not be able to sign my demand, although he is aware of the trouble in the floor and has approved verbally my suggestion.

If the Honourable Staff of Indian Affairs judges my demand a reasonable one I would highly appreciate the care you deign take of the health of the teachers at your service.

Most gratefully yours,

Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist.

Oct. 1, 1940.

Dear Sir:

As the number of pupils staying for midday lunches increases daily, I make it my duty to ask the Honourable Staff of Indian Affairs, to kindly allow me to spend the same amount of $64.00 monthly to cover the expenses of midday meals served at the Restigouche Indian School, from the grave November month to the last of April, abstraction be made of January, as school will then be closed. This sum would not be sufficient to answer our needs during the coldest months, but I generally store up cases of "canned goods" in the early part of the season, which we serve only until the price of potatoes raise from 55 to 60 daily. This foreseeing permits me to provide them a fairly good midday meal.

At present I observed that most of the children remaining for dinner bring only bread and molasses. At first, I thought they wanted to draw my pity, by bringing such a scanty quantity, but the fact that they persist in their small diet, convinces me that necessity forces them to such short allowance.

Truly yours,

Sister M. of the Holy Eucharist.

Ottawa, July 9, 1941.

MEMORANDUM

Dr. H.W. McGill

RE: INDIAN AGENCY

I beg to submit a report of an inspection of the above Agency, made during the last part of June.

SCHOOL:

On June 19th, I visited the Indian Day School and found 150 children present, out of 174 registrations during the current school year. Children were neatly dressed and clean; the class rooms as well as other rooms were spotless.

I took much interest in looking over the exhibit of pupils' work and handcraft, the result of long continuous work on the part of the sisters in charge; sewing, knitting, etc., done by the girls showed me the teaching of the sisters was not fruitless; amongst the collection I found baby-crib and cradle-shirts, pants, dresses and windbreakers, all cut and sewn by the girls; girls' winter coats made from the materials authorized by the Department were most useful and the best practical mean to teach the girls how to make up their own clothing later on; boys' shirts and pants, all made at the school, were to be seen on many of the boys present, and all this made up at a much lower cost than is could purchased ready-made.

The idea of supplying the materials to be made up by the pupils is most practical, providing we have such an interested person to supervise and direct the children, as Sister Mary of the Eucharist, actually in charge.

The boys have made many practical and useful articles, such as chairs and tables, plain, but solid; other fancy things were also made by the boys.

The pupils also took an interest in Red Cross work in its war effort. Fine woolen mittened articles were made from the wool supplied by the Red Cross Society.

Upon my recommendation last year, the amount of twenty-five dollars was allowed for a school garden, and it was a pleasure to see the success achieved so far; the sister told me how the older boys and girls were pleased when garden work began this year; every one has a task to accomplish and the work is changed around, weeding, cultivating, watering; at the centre of the garden, a large clay barrel was sunk half in the ground and kept filled, so that water is at the proper temperature at watering time, rather than using cold water from the well.

The following requests were made by the sister in charge:

Repairs to the sewing machine not to exceed five dollars.

Ten (10) single desks No. 4 for the young ones (actually, many have to sit three on a desk for two)

I recommend that the above requests be granted, providing funds permit.

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Quebec Inspectorate.
Dear Sir,

The last time Mr. Thibault honoured me of his agreeable visit, the Principal of the Festigwache Indian Day School asked our kind Inspector for the addition of ten single pupil desks for the Baby Class. My request was approved, on seeing the pupils sitting on ordinary straight chairs.

I failed to give the necessary details. To avoid deception on their arrival, I want to mention that the desks we would like to match were obtained at Vilas, Montreal; they were walnut in shade, size 22" long, 14" high, and 14" wide. We have pupils of nine years of age, or over.

Assuring my own sincerest thanks, to those of your grateful scholars.

Remain,

Truly yours,

Dear Sir;-

I hereby respectfully give you notice that three storm windows for the dormitory of the teachers' residence of the Restigouche Indian Day School would be needed to maintain the said room in a normal temperature over night. I regret to have to expose especially at such a critical period, to the Honorable Staff of Indian Affairs, such a defect which makes the Sisters suffer from a constant cold during the winter season in spite of the good system of heating which we possess. I trust you will kindly judge my demand a reasonable one since you have always taken a serious care of the health of the teachers at your service. Such benevolence is highly appreciated.

The above work has been examined by a carpenter of the Reserve and he claims to be able to make the three windows for $15; this would be cheaper than buying them already made at the Factory.

Most gratefully yours,

Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist.

D'Arcy Richard,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Seeing the opening of all the schools in our environment on September 2nd, the teaching staff of the Restigouche Indian Day School could not resist to the inspiration of doing likewise. Will the honorable Staff sanction our undertaking? We willingly do it for the welfare of the children and for our own "War Effort" but free of charge to the Honorable Department.

Being in daily contact with the pupils we still notice this year the necessity of serving the midday lunches to the needy ones.

Last fall the grant was reduced to $20.00 monthly. Could I ask for the same this year? I will do my utmost to reckon my expenses so as not to exceed the amount above mentioned.

Thanking you for past favors, I remain

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources.,
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
September 29, 1941.

Dear Sir:

Very careful consideration has been given to the contents of your letter of the 5th instant with reference to serving midday meals at the Restigouche Indian Day School.

As there is no lack of work at the present time it is felt that the parents should be in a position to supply their children with the food required for their midday lunch. However, in order to assist in this regard it has been decided to allow an amount of $90.00 for the academic year 1941-42. It should be completely understood that this is the total amount that will be allowed for midday meal purposes during the current academic year.

In most schools it is the custom to serve a midday lunch during the winter months only and if the same practice is followed at the Restigouche School the amount authorized in this letter should be sufficient to supplement what the children bring with them.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dr. A. Richard,
Indian Agent,
Restigouche, Que.

Dear Sir,

In spite of being in contact with the Indians for five years and have tried to accustom myself to their ways of doing; there is one thing which I still find very hard to overcome. It is the untidiness of unreasonable long hair on boys' head, especially when pediculi have to be controled at school.

I have thought of a mean which would relief many. It would be to equip ourselves with few essential things for hair cutting. The eldest boys of the class could that trade. Meanwhile it would be a practical object lesson on hygiene which is sometimes hard to inculcate in their daily habits.

If the Honourable Staff of Indian Affairs approves my requisition, you will be able to see what the expenses would be by the list below. These articles could be sent directly or taken at the authorized store. I am leaving it always to your benevolance to add or cancel any articles mentioned.

Nov. 6, 1941.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 31st instant asking for further explanation concerning the distribution of the vegetables raised in the school garden of the Restigouche Indian Day School.

The principal admits, kind Mr. Hoey, that she has been thoughtless, in not keeping the products that could easily have been stored up for mid-day meals, such as turnips, onions, cabbages, carrots and beets, which could have been served in raw vegetables.

However, it is to be noted that the chief products of the garden were string beans, corn, and peas. Having no kitchen stove to make the canning, I was forced to give them away during the summer season. The spinach, radishes and lettuce, could neither be kept.

I am looking forward for the day when our small local industry will provide for the chief wants of the mid-day meals.

Truly yours,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,-

With reference to your letter of the 31st. instant requesting definite informations regarding the number of burners, the approximate space where a coal oil stove for the Restigouche Indian Day School, could be placed and if we wanted a stove with or without a warming oven.

I am pleased to send some illustrations which give a clearer idea. Meanwhile I am sorry to see that I have forced you to make new inquiries concerning the matter. I was depending on Mr. Thibault, Inspector, to give the additional details. He had examined the space, taken notes on the number of burners and the needed warming oven. No doubt, the subject must have been forgotten.

Kindly select what you consider best. I am ever pleased and grateful of your final decisions.

Truly yours,

Sister M. of the Holy Eucharist

Dear Sir:

The four burner coal-oil stove is now giving much consolation to the teacher of the Domestic Science and the twenty busy girls of the Restigouche Indian Day School.

After having made an experience we reckoned that 25 gallons of crude coal oil at .18 a gallon would be needed to heat the said stove during the cooking season. A coal oil tank will also be needed to put this oil, at the cost of $8.00 Total expenses $11.75

Truly yours,

July 1, 1942.

Dear Sir,

By the quarterly school return you will notice that eighty-five pupils were registered in the Primary Grade and that fifteen children of school age were refused due to lack of space.

This problem is a serious one for war time! The grave question must have reached the Honourable Staff of Indian Affairs, as this important matter has been discussed by many authorities. To my humble opinion the cheapest way to solve the problem would be to annex a wing to the present building.

Inspectors, Agent and teaching staff all agree that such a construction is indispensable for the accommodation of the registered 184 pupils of the Restigouche Indian Day school; the whole is left to your kind consideration and to the funds available during such a critical time.

I remain ever submitted to your benevolent decision, knowing that you will understand our present situation and will do your utmost to make the much needed change, if there is any possibility of doing so.

Very truly yours,

Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist, r.h.r.

Any action in this regard will have to be postponed until after the war.

Yours very truly,

MEMORANDUM

The Secretary

While away on annual leave, the annexed correspondence directed to you was, likely by error, addressed to me; upon my arrival to the office, I found it with my mail.

The letter is referring to some alterations to be made at our Restigouche Indian Day School.

Inspector of Indian Agencies
Dear Sir,

The plans proposed in favor of our humble industries, for the construction of new apartments in the basement of the Restigouche Indian Day School is too highly appreciated by the members of this residence to remain silent on the matter. The step that you are taking in our behalf proves once again that you wish, not only to help and encourage us, but to sustain those who endeavour to improve the present conditions of the Indians trusted to their care. Yes, it is with all the physical, moral and temporal means put in our power, that we struggle to render life more pleasant to that poor mental destituted class of people. If we seem to gain ground in this subject, it is solely due to the generous cooperation that we constantly receive from our Head Quarters, to whom we owe sincere feelings of gratitude.

These new apartments will permit us to proceed further, and with more accommodation, our present formation and education of ex-pupils in matter of Home Economy and moral conduct. By kind Mr. Thibault's official report of what he has seen in our midst, you will notice that we are reaping real consolation with our Indians mothers and their children, at a very low cost.

Next year in the west basement wing we could temporary place the Manual Training Class of boys and give their present classroom for a sewing room both for pupils and ex-pupils.
Since the new basement rooms will have to be used for classes, at least during war time, do you think the teachers and the pupils would have the proper air space, if the rooms were but seven feet in height? It would be possible to make them higher but the excavation would be more costly, as they would have to dig in the rock and set a drainage system which would lead the waters outside the school yard. If the Honourable Staff of Indian Affairs are not ready to meet the expense of finishing the two rooms of at least nine or ten feet high; could you not finish for this year, one room of nine or ten feet high, with a safe drainage? Thus all would have the satisfaction of a perfect work accomplished and quite safe for classroom purposes.

By such construction, the class floors of the first story will be kept at a normal temperature by the rooms of the basement.

Thanking you for past favors and trusting in a present one,

I remain,
Most gratefully yours,

Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist, r.h.r.
Principal.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Re: Repairs - Restigouche Indian Day School

The Restigouche Reserve has a population of 720 (1939 census). The children of school age (7-16) number 171.

We have on this reserve a three-room school, built in the year 1926-27, with an enrolment at this date of 160. The Sisters in charge of this school have been requesting additional accommodation for the last three or four years. They are particularly anxious for accommodation suitable for the promotion of domestic science and manual training. The Sisters feel that this additional accommodation would enable them to go in more extensively for the remodelling of discarded military clothing, in which they have been outstandingly successful despite their limited classroom space.

Mr. Thibault has made an inspection of this school on more than one occasion. The school has also been visited by Mr. Doucet. Mr. Thibault has recently discussed with me the advisability of excavating under the present building a basement which would provide at least two classrooms and thus relieve the congestion in the regular classrooms. We have been assured by a local contractor, with whom this matter has been discussed, that this excavation work could be undertaken largely by Indian labour, under proper supervision. It is somewhat difficult to state definitely, however, that the construction of the basement is the best and most economical method of providing additional accommodation. It is just possible that an additional classroom might be built adjoining the present school or attached to the present building, at a cost that would not greatly exceed the excavation of the basement. I should add that this is an Indian day school and our educational...
costs per pupil in recent years have been very reasonable. In view of the fact that we may have in this year's Training Appropriation a sum sufficient to buy at least enough supplies for alterations at this school, I would recommend that Mr. Doucet be asked to again visit the Restigouche school and discuss with local contractors familiar with excavation work the desirability of providing a classroom basement at the school and also the approximate cost of the work. It is not anticipated that any difficulty would be experienced in securing the materials necessary for such alterations. These materials would consist in the main of cement.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Repairs, Restigouche Indian Day School

I desire to refer to my memorandum to you dated January 12, 1943. In this connection I am sending forward herewith a report on the Restigouche School, submitted to the Superintendent of Welfare and Training by Mr. A. J. Doucet, who made an inspection of the building last week. The subject matter of Mr. Doucet's memorandum is self-explanatory. He estimates that the cost of the materials necessary to provide three additional rooms at this school would amount to approximately $2,000. These materials would consist in the main of cement, lumber, windows, ten-pan, etc. Mr. Doucet finds it somewhat difficult to estimate the actual labour costs involved. He is of the opinion that these are not likely to exceed $2,500.

In view of the urgent need for accommodation at this school and in view of the fact that the foundations of the school itself are rapidly deteriorating, I would recommend that the school be reconstructed along the lines suggested in Mr. Doucet's memorandum. These alterations, when completed, will give us three well equipped classrooms, particularly well adapted for manual training for boys and vocational instruction for girls.

While no provision is made in either the estimates of this year or next year for this work, the officials of the Welfare and Training Service inform me that they are likely to have sufficient funds to buy the materials out of this year's appropriations and they feel that the costs of labour might be secured from

p.t.o.
next year's appropriations. This work, in our judgment, should be undertaken at the earliest possible date in the spring. It can be undertaken without interruption in any serious sense of the work of the classrooms. It would be appreciated if I could have your decision in respect to this matter in due course.

Director.
Memorandum:

MR. HOBY

Re: Visit to Restigouche Day School

As directed, I have studied the various solutions in regard to increasing the accommodation of the Restigouche Indian Day School. I studied:

1. The possibility of adding a wing to the present building;
2. The possibility of finding a temporary locality;
3. The possibility of building a basement under the present building.

As far as building an extension to the present building, it appears that the plan of the school does not lend itself very easily to such a procedure. Building a symmetrical wing at the North of the building would require hallways in order that there might be communication between the two buildings; these hallways would necessarily break up two classrooms so that this plan would, I believe, not increase the accommodation of the school. Furthermore, there would still remain to correct certain errors made in the construction of the present building. There is no foundation; the floors are exceedingly cold, being composed of the sub-flooring, paper, and the finished floor. This cannot keep warm enough so that the occupants and the teachers complain of cold feet. The complaint is justified. Moreover, joists and beam which are surrounded by dirt have greatly decayed, in fact some of them should be replaced immediately. This decay will continue to the walls, in fact in some parts the floor has already turned black. The walls which are covered with earth must necessarily be decaying. A few more years and complete change of the base of the building will be necessary. This would entail a considerable expense without remedying the situation.

The possibility of finding a temporary locality was investigated. There are but few buildings, such as the old teachers' residence and possibly the old school of the white population, but these buildings would require considerable repair, the payment of rent and would still prove to be very unsatisfactory.

To my mind there is but one solution which would give more room and at the same time remedy the cause of decay in the present building. That is to build a complete foundation beneath the present building. I would, therefore, recommend that the present building be raised approximately 2½ feet and excavated to give a space of 9 feet, thus providing for a boys' workshop and two classrooms. This is not a very difficult proposition as the building
is but a frame building and of one story except for the small classroom which is of two stories. I have required two men to dig below this building a four-foot hole to ascertain the condition of the sub-soil. We struck rock, but rock of a nature that is more like partly frozen soil. It can be broken fairly easily with picks. I have checked this as thoroughly as possible with Mr. Beaulieu who has considerable experience with this kind of work in the surrounding communities. We are convinced that this can fairly easily be done, especially with the hydraulic drill. Mr. Beaulieu, who has impressed me as being very reliable, is willing to use the equipment that he has and take full responsibility for raising building the foundation, putting in the drainage and finishing the concrete columns at the salary of $10.00 a day. It is difficult to estimate the time that it would take but with the help of four or five men the work could be done in six or eight weeks. I, therefore, would strongly recommend this solution.

Respectfully submitted,

A.J. Doucet.
Ottawa, February 19, 1943.
