March 3, 1943.

Dear Inspector Doucet,

Knowing that the arduous work of the plan of the Restigouche Indian Day School is confided to you, kind Mr. Doucet, the local authorities have considered it their duty to present you their humble suggestions on the matter. May they spare you a few of your well-employed moments, by helping you to solve problems that inevitably occur in such undertakings.

You will kindly notice that we have thought of a bath room and toilets in the five feet space, where we had spoken to place the hall. Such an apartment is almost indispensable.

The stair leading to the work shop had to be placed in the class room, (although separated by a wall) as the pipes of the toilets prevent to pass the stair in the cellar on the north side. Besides the porch-like (13) could be used to enter wood in the cellar.

What do you think, Mr. Doucet, of the annexed hall marked (2) which could be used for a gallery? For our part we would highly appreciate such benevolence on your part if you would kindly grant it to us. After a close examination, you will also notice all the advantages derived from it.

The actual cellar stair (No.19) would answer well for a meat store-room. Would it not? The space marked (20) could be kept for a vegetable store-room. Thus the kitchen would organized as a permanent one.
If we would have the basement doors at each end, with a porch it would be easier to clear the snow off and maintain the classes in a warmer temperature.

We are ever ready to sanction your final decision,

I remain,

Most gratefully yours,

Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist, r.h.r.
Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist, r.h.r.

Mr. Alp. Doucet, Inspector,
Training Division,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
Restigouche, March 9th, 1943.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa,

In reply to your letter of the 1st instant with reference to the repairs at the Restigouche Indian Day School, I beg to inform the Department Mr Beaulieu accepts to supervise the work at the rate of $10.00 a day, it being understood that he would use his own equipment, except, as understood with Mr Doucet, for the rent of 25 to 30 jacks at the cost of about $60.00 to $75.00 to raise up the building. This work should take 36 to 38 jacks, but has himself only 5 jacks.

Mr Beaulieu and I don't expect the ground to be in good condition to start the work before about the first week of June, if ground is good before that period I will inform you at once.

Mr Beaulieu promised to be at the job when weather conditions will permits, and I am of the opinion this man can make good work; I recommend him to the Department as well as I recommended him to Mr Doucet.

Indian Agent.

Yours truly,

I beg to inform the Department I have received the material requested from the Department by the purchasing order No 17106 for Indian School, except the Ten-Test and the Drain tiles which will come later.

After the arrival of this material I had it examined by Mr Beaulieu who found everything correct except the doors and the frames.

I beg to inform the Department I am very uneasy since few days concerning the work to be done at Restigouche Indian Day School about June. I would like to know if for the Department, Ottawa, the men have to be on the same laws than the Companies for the payment of the taxes, selective service, compensation, bonus, etc., according to wages and dependents.

I don't know the first letter in that question, I remember I received few circular letters concerning the proceedings when men are employed, but when I was informed this law don't concern the Indians working on the Indian Reserve, I don't know where these letters went, I don't find them. But for the few white men working on this job I believe the only way for me not to make any mistake will be to send the pay list to Ottawa every week, and to make the pay when the cheques come from your office. For the Indians when working on the Reserve having nothing to pay in taxes I can pay them here if money.

Please inform me about this question for the pay of the men, but being very scarce to make mistake I hope the Department will accept to make the pay.

Restigouche, 30 Juin, 1943.

Branche des Affaires Indiennes, Ottawa, Canada.

J'ai le regret de vous annoncer que nous avons encore frapper un noeud. Nous manquons de bois pour nos formes pour finir la fondation de cette École. Mr Beaulieu dit que les dimensions de cette fondation ont été beaucoup étirées depuis que les estimés pour le bois ont été faits, mais que le bois n'a pas été tiré. En plus plus il en faut pour les fondations du corridor reliant le couvent à l'école. Après avoir fait des calculs il a trouvé qu'il faudrait encore 2000 fts de planche polies et 1500 fts de 2 X 4 pour les poteaux de ces formes. Nous avions déjà parlé de cela et vous aviez dit de commencer et nous verrons ensuite. Il y a encore tout le bout de la partie est et le corridor à faire, ensuite une coulée de pieds de haut pour finir quelques autres côtés. Il faut faire le deuxième mur du dehors avant de commencer de couler le ciment. Ce mur ne prendra pas autant de temps parce qu'il y a moins d'ajustage, nous pensions de commencer cette semaine ce coulage mais je crois que ce manque de bois va nous retarder. Le creusement est est très difficile et dur surtout pour le corridor. Il faudra aussi creuser le centre, la pluie nous retarde beaucoup dans toutes ces opérations, la boue empêche les hommes de aller vite.

Pour moins retarder envoyer-moi donc un message si accepté afin de faire polir ce bois et l'avoir dans le plus court temps. Les hommes font de la bonne ouvrage et ne perdent pas de temps.

Agent.
Restigouche, June 30, 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

RE: School

I regret to inform you that we are again experiencing difficulty. We are short of lumber to finish the forms for the foundation of the school. Mr. Beaulieu claims that the dimensions of the foundation have been enlarged since the estimates for lumber were prepared while the latter have not been enlarged. Further, lumber is required for the foundations of the hall connecting the convent to the school. Mr. Beaulieu figures that an additional quantity of 2000' of dressed board and 1500' of 2 X 4 will be required for these forms. We had mentioned this to you, but you advised us to start the work and that you would consider the matter later on. There still remain the end of the easterly section and the hall to be done as well as a couple of feet in height to be finished on some of the other sides. The second outside wall must be built before the cement can be poured. This wall will not require so much time to build as it will require fewer adjustments. We expected to start pouring this week, but this shortage of lumber will delay matters. Digging is very difficult especially for the hall. It will be necessary also to dig in the center; rain also delays operations.

To expedite matters, will you kindly send me a message (telegram?) if you accept, in order that the lumber may be dressed as soon as possible. The workmanship is good and the men do not waste any time.

(Sgd) J. Art. Richard

Agent.

Dear Mr. Doucet:

I have a letter from the Principal of the Restigouche Indian Day School in which she states that, owing to the fact that two new teachers are being added to the staff for the coming academic year, it will be necessary for some changes to be made in the teachers' living quarters and she states that the necessary work can be done for $175.00, or possibly less. Dear Mr. Phelan:

Enclosed please find a copy of an order for school supplies. An agent was in to see me so I picked out the material needed for the new rooms. I would like to insist on the black board 'Dollard'. If we can not obtain this we will have to take Hyloplate. They will also need a dozen common chairs, these for the sewing room. As far as the tables go I intend to get a price for having them made according to a plan I think will be more efficient than those we can buy today and at a greatly reduced cost.

As I mentioned to you while in Ottawa the roof of the school needs repair. It is a question of replacing shingles broken and others that were wrongly placed. I will have this done as it leaks at several places. The school would need painting; we have replaced parts that will need to be done for it is new wood but the whole school needs it badly. For about fifteen (15) dollars I can have the roof done. The rest will take about 30 gallons of paint. I could have this done on the same plan as the rest of the work if you think that would be satisfactory.

I am having the Eel River School prepared for painting the interior. Do you wish to have the exterior done also. It certainly needs it badly. I could use the same plan as at the Restigouche School. The foundation should also need repairs. It is breaking away at a few places. "A stitch in time saves nine"

Yours truly,

P. S. If I could have the blackboard soon enough I could have them placed while I am here. Please check on the Plastic rock for the floors, I have heard nothing about it since we ordered it at the beginning of July.
Ottawa,

Dear Mr. Doucet:

With reference to your letter of the 9th instant, it is noted that the repairs required to the roof of the Restigouche School will cost approximately $15.00. You may also have the school painted, but it is regretted that you did not state the colour of paint you wish, so that the order for 30 gallons could have been placed through our Purchasing Branch. However, if you secure competitive prices you may purchase it from the firm quoting the lowest price, but you should forward all quotations with the account. The order for the rock wool was sent to the Storrar Manufacturing Company on July 10 and should have been delivered before this. I am writing to the firm today.

You may arrange for the exterior painting of the Eel River School, as well as the interior painting. You may also have the foundation repaired. I will try to have the blackboard shipped as soon as possible. So far this morning I have been unable to get in touch with the Stationery Office.

I presume you can purchase the 12 common chairs locally.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

The work is progressing slowly. I have been unable to obtain carpenters. I expect to obtain a few retired men in a few days, to adjust the windows and doors. The men are very uneasy. In fact for a few hours yesterday I had but two left. At times for certain work I have to pitch in myself, at times I feel like taking up carpentry work myself in order to get finished with the job. I feel that the treasury department have been very unfair and have put an unnecessary load on my shoulders. Six weeks and still no bonus so wonder the men are uneasy. If I do not get the bonus before Saturday I am just as well to pack up and leave. As far as the Indians go I thought you were following the regulation no tax no bonus as for the teachers. However I am sending the forms completed; some could not be signed by the Indian himself as they have left for the States, the information is verified by the agent ans is therefore accurate. I cannot see any reason why the bonus for the forms sent in has not been sent in the meantime, this would have allowed me to progress more satisfactorily with the work.

In their requisition for school material the teachers have $150 for sewing tables, I can have these made here by the manufacturing Co.s for less than a $100. A table 2'6" X 4'0" for $7.50 a piece. I will also have the cupboards for domestic science made by the carpenters. I will also get a quotation on a kitchen range. If the teacher's desk on the quotation I sent you has not been purchased it should be cancelled and a secretary with a few drawers be substituted. It should cost about $12. I will return this requisition in a few days.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Hoy:

The work at the school is drawing to a close. I have just received 4 blackboards. I have spread the ground that banked the school before it was raised on the school grounds and approaches making them level so that the spring water will not gather. This ground is a sticky clay and should be covered with gravel. It would take about 25 truck loads to cover it, possibly less. I can have this hauled for $4.00 a load. If this should be approved please wire me the answer.

I went over and examined the Eel River school Sunday and I find that it is not worth painting the East side the siding and the roof are in a very bad condition. The extensive rains that we have been having has caused the plaster to fall from the walls of the cloak rooms. To repair this school adequately would cost between 4 and 5 hundred dollars. If the Department intends to centralize these reserves as in P.S., this would be a useless expense. To preserve this school the following should be done: Repair the roof, replace all the siding on the east side and replace broken siding on the others, repair the foundation, repair the windows placing storm windows, repair the cloak rooms. Please let me know what I should do. The foundation and windows should be done.

I hope to be home in the course of next week.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

The wonderful improvement made at the Restigouche Indian Day School is now concluded. And it is a delight for the members of this residence to express to the honorable Staff of Indian Affairs their sincere gratitude for the beautiful work accomplished. Deign accept our heartfelt thanks for such a favor and for having sent in our midst kind Mr. Doucet Inspector, to direct and control this laborious undertaking. Sincere congratulations are due him, for the cleverness with which he has overcome all the difficulties, so as to lead this arduous task, to such a successful end. He acted as a conscientious man, owing to your benevolent cooperation and the steadfast solicitude of your devoted Inspector, our school has not only been enlarged, made more comfortable but embellished. You can be proud of it, as I may say; it has become the admiration of all. You have put at our disposal, roomy and well-equipped apartments where we hope that our Indian pupils will receive manual training and vocational instruction which will permit them to confront the tasks awaiting them on their departure from school. Each one of us will do our utmost to prove to you that you have not collaborated with us in vain.

On January 13, 1947, Mr. M. A. Hoey, sent a circular letter to the teaching staff of the Dominion stating that few improvements should be made in the educational programme. Immediately, we have tried, slowly but surely to annex more manual work in our teaching, so as not
to make it so abstract and academic. The attempt has proved that the advice given by our kind Superintendent of Welfare and Training was worthy of efforts.

We will now be in the position to realize in full your proposed plans, always endeavoring to remain in the just limits.

Once again sincere thanks for all what you have so kindly done, to promote the general welfare of our Indians.

Yours gratefully yours,

Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist, P.M.

Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist, Prin;

D.M. Richard

His approbation pleased me and I do not want to quit before thanking the Head quarters of the Federal Department for having trusted me this preparation. I also want to thank you very sincerely for having sacrificed one of your learned employers to inspect the daily work. In spite of my fifteen years' experience on heavy construction, I admit frankly that having Mr. Inspector Doucet at my side all summer, I have learned many new things which I had no notion of before.

Schools:

Revisited: It was a very pleasant surprise for me to see the great improvements accomplished to the building since my last visit; it is a realization of what I had suggested previously, except that it is much better than I had ever expected. You may have an idea of the exterior by comparing the enlarged photographs which I made before and after the alterations.

The classroom desks came in just before I left, the blackboard was already on the wall and the floor had received a coat of plastic composition over the cement, which makes it more sanitary, noiseless to walk on and so much easier to clean; there is plenty of light from the south side and the walls and ceiling are painted in light soft color, contributing to make it an ideal classroom.

The room at the back is to be used for manual training has much better lighting than the one used up-stairs in the east, the floor has also received a coating of plastic and the walls painted in light color give the room a cheerful look.

The furnace is the same one but has been put on new foundation with additional pipes to supply heat to the new addition; large space is allowed for fuel wood storage with convenient entrance from back of the building.

The third room is quite large and is to be used for domestic science, sewing room, etc. The lighting is very good, there is a good sink with hot and cold running water, each side of the sink there are cupboards, the top of which are covered with masonite as well as the wall, cupboards are also built above the sink, as well as along part of the south wall; a new white enamelled wood burning cook stove was also installed. There are also eleven work tables, with drawers, made locally strongly built of hard wood, ten of them having a masonite top; the plain top one intended to be used for the knitting machines.

The basement of the passage between the school and the teachers' residence has been arranged for a root cellar.

All the lumber used for the cement forms was used in making dividing walls, ceilings, and cupboards.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Restigouche Indian Day School

I am advised by Mr. Doucet that all labour returns in connection with the reconstruction of the above-mentioned school have now reached this Department and have been forwarded to your office.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
In regard to the provisions and supplies for the noonday lunch at the Restigouche Indian Day School, I wish to draw your attention to the fact that, if we are going to teach Domestic Science, we must furnish the supplies necessary for this purpose.

On breaking down this item to the basis of one lesson, the following amounts are arrived at: approximately 70 cents per lesson for one group. There would be 30 lessons a week, which would give us $14.00 a month for 10 months = $140.00. I would, therefore, recommend that we allow a grant of $150.00 for the teaching of Domestic Science. The disposal of this prepared material may, with advantage, be supplied to the needy children at the school.

As regards the grant of $200.00 for clothing, I wish to draw your attention to the fact that clothing for the aged and destitute is supplied by the Restigouche Sewing Club. This would come under "Welfare" rather than "Education". I think it is advisable to have these needy people provided for in this manner rather than furnishing them directly. It would also constitute quite a saving. The amount that would be required for this work is not yet available. I will, however, on my next visit to Restigouche, determine the amounts required for this work and will submit them at that time.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

Cher Monsieur Doucet:

Un mot de nos travaux pour vous dire que Beaulieu n'a pas pu aller sous l'école de Eel River pour placer des poteaux de fer. Les soupiraux de chaque côté ne sont que des dalots boisés en cèdre qui vont à une grille dans le plancher de l'école, il lui aurait fallu faire un grand trou dans la fondation ou le plancher, alors il a laisser faire. Il a fait une bonne ouvrage, il a dépensé plus de lambris de planche que prévu parce que le vieux était avec une rainure et le neuf comme celui de Restigouche. Presque toute la façade est en neuf et beaucoup des autres côtés.

J'ai a vous annoncer que les tableaux noirs de l'école des petits du côté ouest viennent mouillés par l'eau des murs. Fred dit qu'il va falloir mettre des baguettes de bois en arrière pour l'air. Que pensez vous de cela. Aussi il fait plus froid dans cette classe qu'ailleurs, même en fermant les autres conduits d'air chaud. Nous avons pensé être de l'Eucharistie et moi de mettre des pentures au châssis en avant de la fournaise dans l'escalier pour l'ouvrir et envoyer la chaleur dans l'école. Autrement il va falloir mettre un petit poêle. L'autre classe du côté est est chaude par le poêle de cuisine.

Si vous pensez qu'autre chose pourrait être fait s'il vous plaît de le dire de suite. J'en- graisse maintenant que je ne travaille plus aux taxes le samedi après-midi. Je N'ai pas encore reçu l'argent du bonus pour le mois de septembre, les gens s'informent souvent. J'espère que Madame ne m'en veut plus.

Bien à vous,

[Signature]

Pour faire suite à ma lettre vous annonçant l'humidité et le froid dans la classe des petits, la partie ouest du sous-basement, je dois vous avouer qu'avec l'augmentation du froid la température y devient presque intenable pour l'institutrice et les enfants, qui au lieu d'être noirs deviennent bleus. J'y suis allé hier matin et réellement cela m'a fait pitié pour ces enfants. Les murs sont trempés, on y voit l'eau couler, surtout au bout du ouest, le tuyau d'air chaud étant seulement à l'autre bout ne peut envoyer assez de chaleur pour sécher et réchauffer l'autre bout. J'ai fait examiner cela par Fred Beaulieu, qui en est venu à la conclusion qu'il faut y installer un petit poêle tout à fait le long du mur ouest avec un long tuyau qui irait rejoindre la cheminée en passant le long des tuyaux d'air chaud, et en y perçant un trou, les autres trous sont trop bas.

Je comprends que cela va encore coûter quelqu'argent, mais nous ne voyons aucun autre moyen d'y remédier. Nous avons ouvert le châssis en face de la fournaise, mais c'est trop loin pour sécher et réchauffer tout l'appartement. Fred est beaucoup occupé, ne pourra venir avant la semaine prochaine. Nous avons pensé que si nous pouvions trouver un petit poêle à acheter cela irait mieux que de prendre le petit qui chauffe l'eau l'été, ôter toutes les connections, y mettre des plugs, un petit poêle carré chaufferait mieux que le petit de la fournaise.

Si vous pouviez me donner votre opinion immédiatement comment remédier à cet inconvénient, je serais bien content, cela se ferait pendant que je puis avoir Fred, car si je ne le prends pas au commencement de la semaine, je ne sais quand je l'aurai. Tout le monde court après lui.

Votre tout dévoué,

[Signature]

Branche des Affaires Indiennes, Ottawa, Canada.

Je vous envoie les comptes pour l'installation d'un poêle dans la classe des petits de l'école indienne de Restigouche.

J'ai bien trouvé moi-même que le prix est haut, mais j'ai suivi cet ouvrage, et après réflexion, je pense que tout est bien correct. Un tuyau très long qui traverse la cloison, dans un bon gros bloc de ciment, en arrière de l'escalier, tourne vers la fournaise de quelques pieds et s'en va à travers les tuyaux d'air chaud dans la cheminée, où un trou creusé dans la brique y reçoit le tuyau dans le ciment. Ce tuyau est suspendu à deux pieds du plafond par des fils de fer rapprochés. Je n'y vois aucun danger pour le feu après toutes les précautions prises.

Alfred Beaulieu a travaillé seul pour cette installation, ses oiseaux étaient allés à Campbellton et quelques jours de repos étaient nécessaires. Un homme seul dans ce posage de tuyau ne va pas vite, le ciment a aussi pris beaucoup de temps pour un seul homme.

Je vous assure que petit poêle avec cette longueur de tuyau donne une bonne chaleur et qu'il fait bon dans la classe surtout ces jours-ci avec une température au-dessous de zéro jour et nuit.

J'espère que ces comptes seront acceptés sans difficulté étant donnée l'urgence d'une telle installation, et les prix des matériaux.

Agent des Indiens.
Restigouche, Dec. 17, 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.

I am sending you the accounts for the installation of a stove in the smaller pupils' class at the Indian school of Restigouche.

At first, I thought that the price was rather high, but I followed the work closely and on reason thought I believe that everything is in order. There is a long pipe which runs through the partition in a large cement block behind the stairs; it then turns towards the furnace and reaches the chimney between the hot air ducts where it enters in a hole provided in the brick. This pipe is hung two feet from the ceiling by several strands of wire and I believe that every precaution has been taken against fire.

Alfred Beaulieu worked alone on this job, his assistants having gone to Campbellton and a few days rest were necessary. Such work requires a great deal of time when it is done by only one man.

I can assure you that the small stove gives off a good heat thanks to this long pipe, and that it is comfortable in the class, especially these days when the thermometer goes below zero night and day.

I trust that these accounts will be approved in view of the urgency of the work and the prices of material.

(Sgd) Art. Richard,
Indian Agent.

Restigouche, January 22nd, 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Canada.

It is at the knowledge of the Department that in the Restigouche Indian Day School yard are two big and old poplars measuring at the stub about 24 inches and a height of over 50 feet. These poplars are very old, drying and rotten, very dangerous for the pupils in the school yard, while snow storm, and for the other peoples passing on the main road. Already some branches are broken at the top remaining up among the others. At every wind storm some branches brake and fall down.

So I thought, while men are cutting the trees at the Monastery and in the white school yard, to benefit of the services of these experienced men to cut also ours down and to clean the yard. There are 3 white men and two indian men and one indian horse working at this job. Mr Alfred Beaulieu took by verbal contract the job to cut those two trees and to clean well the yard with the responsibility of the damages to the fence for the amount of twelve ($12.00) dollars having all the necessary riggins. I think I cannot have this work done at better price and to be sure to have it done correctly.

I hope this Indian Agent action be approved by the Department.

Indian Agent.

The present is ask the Department an amount of about $20.00 to level the west part of the pupils garden at Restigouche School.

This part was very wet and it was impossible to use it for the cultivation of vegetables... Last fall, when they have repaired the School, all the ground taken off from around the building, was hauled on this part of the garden, but it is not levelled and a certain quantity of black ground should be hauled and mixed to improve the land. The amount asked would be also to buy a certain quantity of manure and fertilizer.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Mr. Richard, Indian Agent, just told me that the Honourable Department did not see the need of wooden floors in the basement rooms of the Mistigouche Day School.

Whenever I receive a decision from the Honourable Staff, I generally accept it as being the wisest thing to do; but in this present case I feel it my duty to give more explanations regarding the matter, as I see that Mr. M. J. Scott was absent, thus unable to give you the necessary information.

When your Inspector visited us in early April, he saw the water streaming down the walls to the floors and noticed how cold and damp these rooms were. He stated, "At the closing of the school say a word, and we will do something! It is really too cold."

On the first week of May, while I was holding a class of sewing with the Indian mothers, we were suddenly interrupted by a slop running in the apartments. After a week's time, seeing the water found no outlets, and was beginning to smell bad, the Visitor, Mr. John Caplin, with the help of school boys took out over fifty tubs, or twelve gallons each, of foul water. Can you imagine the condition of the clothes in cupboards and the cleaning we had to go there after? There was hardly any snow this winter, nor will it turn out if we undertake another winter in the same conditions. Presently, in spite of the warm weather, the dampness in the cupboards makes the clothes mild. During the winter months, the clothing would stick in the thick frost of the cupboard walls.

As far as the floors are concerned, I feel unable to undertake another year in the same conditions. I am waiting for the closing of the school to undergo a serious operation due to unhealthy apartment, without mentioning the ramifications connected therein. If school room was not in the basement we would simply ask you to close the women and boys' sewing club, thus only a small part of the time would be spent in the said apartment. But if you provide us with a trained officer next year, we will surely stand in need of all the rooms we presently have. I trust that next year, the pupils will be used to their new teachers and will attend school as regularly as in preceding years. In fact, changes among the teachers always register less attendance for the first year. Rather the teachers understand better how to get the children, or the children themselves, at any rate there is more satisfaction and encouragement.

Since we are presently obliged to remain from eight o'clock in the morning till five o'clock in the evening in such rooms, I dare not ask our other provincial for a substitute in these conditions. I prefer to suffer there myself, although I sincerely feel excessively tired out, so to prevent another one to face the same difficulties and so does the other man. I asked the Indian agent if he found I was exaggerating in any statements which I was forwarding; he said, "What you say there, Sister, it's the truth. When I go in for only few minutes, I feel it myself."

Some pupils in the primary grade could not stand it and the doctor took them to remain home.

I remember of having once said to me, in default, "I would be in need of certain things sometimes but I dare not ask for them." He answered "Ask and you will receive." It is with a sincere confidence that I beg this favor, for my long experience at your service has proved to me many a times that needed favors were ever granted.

Sister Mary of the Holy Sacrifice,

Sr. M. A. Hoey,
Sup't. of Welfare & Training,

Honorable Sir:

First, I should say that I thankfully appreciate all that has hitherto been done by your Department to ameliorate the sanitary conditions of our Indian School house in Restigouche.

Still, I think it imperative to respectfully inform you of the following: In spite of the mats and linoleum that have been put on—a while ago—over the floors, the dampness and uncomfortableness of the place is about the same; the linoleum is soaked through and will hardly last much longer; the wall crevices have widened, so in the least thaw the rooms are flooded again.

I just wonder what could be done!... I wish I could exactly say... May be a wooden floor put on?... A clapboard of "ten test" over the walls?... I wonder!

Mr. J. Thibault, Inspector from your Department has seen by himself how insalubrious are the rooms of the lower story of the house and could tell you that I am in no way amplifying; he would be able—at the same time—to suggest what improvement would practically be possible.

So, I should be very much obliged to you, Honorable Sir, if you kindly consider this over and have the needed repairs made as soon as you possibly can. The children's health—and the Sisters' also—owing to severe colds ensuing from the state of the building are being dangerously exposed.

In trustful hopes, and with respectful regards,

I am, Honorable Sir,

Yours sincerely,

Sister Mary of the Annunciation, Superior General.

With this arrangement we will be able to secure what is required before the next heating season commences.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR THIBAULT, following his inspection of the RESTIGOUCHE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL - report dated April 10, 1945.

The school building stands well after all the improvements made in 1943. However, the two rooms in the basement will require more finishing if they are intended to be used for the next school year. I was informed that the Superior General of the Community will not allow any Sister to remain in the actual rooms, on account of the continuous cold cement floor and the dampness of the walls. The improvement would consist in a wooden floor and covering of the walls on three sides in each room, as the walls on the side of the furnace room are not affected by dampness. I recommend that an estimate of the cost of the suggested improvements be requested from the Agent for the consideration of our Branch.
Re: Floors and walls in basement of Restigouche School.

I enclose herewith the estimates given by Mr. Alfred Beaulieu, for the floors and walls in the basement of the Restigouche Indian Day School, as recommended by Inspector Thibault.

Dear Mr. Armstrong;

I hereby respectfully give you notice that the aqueduct pipe which supplies water to the Restigouche Indian Day School and teachers' residence is out of order. It is impossible for me to state the exact cost of this work as we are unable to see what and where the trouble is.

Re: Transportation of pupils to school.

Many Indian families of this Reserve are residing far from the Indian School, and they are forced to keep their children at home during winter time on account of the bad roads, cold, and stormy weather.

These families ask me to apply to the Department in order to organize the transportation of the children to the school during the next winter.

Dear Sir,

When the carpenters made the walls and floor to the basement rooms of the Restigouche Indian Day School, they were forced to undo the 21' by 14' cupboard, as they were unable in spite of their endeavouring to remove it in one block. I have asked them to remake it but they affirmed that it was not on their contract.

I am humbly asking the Honourable Staff of Indian Affairs to kindly permit our Indian Agent, Mr. E. Arsenault, to have it made in the nearest future possible as I have no place to protect the sewing supplies. It is impossible to pile things on the floor and kindly remember that I am using that apartment for dining-room, kitchen, sewing-room, etc., occupation. Besides we have over fifty different seniors attending these courses in a week so I absolutely need a part of the cupboard to separate everybody's work, may it be crocheting, sewing or knitting.

Not more than $43.00 worth of lumber paint and nails would be required. For the labour it would depend what salary would be given. I am positive that it took three days to two men to make it the last time, and I find that it is a too heavy work to undertake it myself with the boys of the Senior class.

Trusting on your well-known benevolence,

I remain,

Gratefully yours,

Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist, R.S.F.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

N.B.: The labour for this work would cost about $50.00; I recommend that cupboard as it is absolutely necessary for the domestic science course.

E. Arsenault, Agent

Dear Sir,

Since the number of teachers has increased at the Restigouche Indian Day School, we have always done our best to find space to room ourselves in the building granted us.

Having presently at our disposal such a spacious sewing room and having the small sewing room on the second floor of the Indian school left unused, I am asking the Honourable Department of Indian Affairs if you would please permit us to make a wall in that apartment and allow us the use of it for two nuns' cells that is bedrooms. Whenever we have visitors some teachers have to give their beds and sleep on tables in the workroom.

If you would kindly permit us the use of that apartment, I would have the boys' of the Senior Class make the walls and set in the door. I foresee that the lumber for that purpose would not cost more than $48.00 to $49.00.

Truly yours,

S.M.of the Holy Eucharist, r.s.f.

In any case, the Department does not think it would be advisable to use the room as a bedroom.

I also received your letter of the 22nd ultimo with regard to the cupboard. Explanations re Painting and varnishing the 2 Rooms in the basement of the Restigouche School.

It is certainly by error that Mr Beaulieu has not mentioned in his estimates the varnishing and painting of walls and floors of the two rooms repaired in the basement of the Restigouche School. I believe it is also by an oversight that Mr Doucet did not mention the fact to Mr Beaulieu, when they talked the matter over at my residence this summer.

When Mr Beaulieu had about finished the work, he informed me of the matter; I had not the time to inform the Department because Mr Beaulieu was hired elsewhere few days after, and by doing so the job could not be completed.

I have therefore asked Mr Beaulieu to varnish the floors and paint the walls. I left after for my vacation and it is why I have myself forgotten to inform the Department before now.

Please refer this note to Mr Doucet. Hoping the Department will understand that this work was absolutely necessary for new walls & floor.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Replying to your letter of the 16th instant, I regret very much that the Department does not seem to approve the request of the Sisters of the Restigouche Indian Day School, in connection with the small sewing room at the second floor.

Without having the intention to criticise your decision about that matter, it is my opinion that I have to recommend you the request of the Sisters.

I am aware that the Sisters are short of bedrooms in their convent since the increasing of teachers for the Indian School. It is a fact, that they are obliged to sleep on tables of the kitchen, when they receive the visit of other nuns.

Lately, the community of the Restigouche Sisters, have received the visit of their Provincial Superior from Rimouski, and no doubt, that again, two nuns have been obliged to sleep on tables to secure rooms for the important visitors.

You will admit with me, that it is a bed in an emergency...........

As I may understand, this occurs only when they receive visitors, and the small sewing room of the second floor would be used only occasionally as bedroom.

I believe also, that this space could be used in the meantime as library for the pupils; few shelves on the walls would be sufficient for this purpose.

I beg the Department to study again his decision in order to secure to the teachers of the Indian Day School, a proper accommodation for the night.

Hoping my letter will receive your usual kind attention.

E. Arsenault, Agent.
Ottawa, 1st December, 1945.

Mr. E. Arsenault, Indian Agent, Restigouche, Quebec.

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo replying to my letter of the 16th ultimo regarding the use of the sewing room in the Restigouche School for a bedroom. We have again considered both your letter of November 23rd and October 16th and we do not see any reason for changing our previous decision as conveyed to you in my letter of November 16th.

I also wish to direct your attention to the second paragraph of my letter of the 16th to which you have not yet replied.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

I have authorized the payment of $423.44 for material furnished by Alfred Beaulieu for the improvement of the basement in the Restigouche Indian Day School. Ottawa, October 1, 1946.

The following is a brief report of my visit to the Restigouche Agency July 13th, 14th and August 26th to 28th inclusive.

RESTIGOUCHE RESERVE

SCHOOL

Two-roomed building is in very good condition. Teacher's residence is also in good repair. There has been some trouble, after heavy rains, of the water backing up in the school basement. I examined the disposal bed which drains the sewage system and discovered that it is filled up completely and will not absorb the sewage as well as the extra rain water running into it. It is my opinion that the sewer pipes from the school should be connected to the sewage system from the Agent's house, which drains directly into the Bay of Chaleur. If this is done it would correct the trouble.

Water Supply: The water pipes leading from the water system are old and corroded and leaking in several places. These pipes should be cut off where they join the main water system and a new connection made. This work, of course, cannot be done this year as pipes are not available. Arrangements, however, should be made in next year's estimates to provide money for this work. It is suggested that Agent Arsenault be requested to have a plumbing expert from Campbellton inspect both the sewer and water system to the school, and submit a tender on the cost of materials and labour so that the sum required can be provided and the work commence early next spring.

Note: Three small storm windows for the cellar in the teacher's residence are authorized to be purchased.
FORMER TEACHER'S RESIDENCE

This building was moved back and placed on blocks immediately behind the new teacher's residence. It is a large two-story building approximately 28' x 30' and appears to be in a very good condition. It is now used by the teachers as a store house for trunks, screens, doors, etc. I asked the Sister Superior of the school if they had any great need for the building and what objection would they have if it was moved to some other location and made available for some other service. She stated that there would be no objection on their part if we took the building and a small shed was constructed to provide storage facilities. This old residence is being neglected and if nothing is done to repair the roof then it will become a derelict and will have to be torn down. On my next visit to this Agency, I intend to investigate this building further and will make a definite recommendation as to what should be done with it.

X X X

J.E. Morris,

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, OTTAWA.

Attention: Mr. Phelan.

Re: Restigouche Indian Day School.

The sewer pipe which provides service for the above mentioned school, blocked up and the sewage backed into the basement to a depth of one to three inches. Note. This school is located on church own property and the sewer pipe from the school connects up with the sewer system to a cess pool, located on church property.

The stench in the basement with a temperature of 90 degrees, was almost overpowering. You can imagine the work required to clean up this mess, as the water had saturated into the cement floor, partitions and benches. This is the third time that the sewage has backed into the cellar since January 1947, and the Agent reports that this is a regular occurrence, happening several times each year. Mr. Arsenault, had to practically beg a man to clean out the sewer, and the basement, in fact, Mr. Arsenault had to agree to work with him or he would not even attempt to do the job at all.

It is my opinion that the only way to correct this stoppage in the sewer is to lay a new sewer line, draining the school direct into the Restigouche River. This is the same system that has been in use for the Agent's house and Office and since it was constructed a number of years ago, has not given any trouble.

The shortest distance from the school to Restigouche River is 920 feet. Therefore, 920 feet of 6 inch Tile Pipe would have to be purchased. The cost of pipe and labour should not exceed $1200.00. This figure, of course, is only a guess. I would suggest that the Purchasing Agent endeavour to obtain the price and quantity of pipe required.

Immediate action must be taken, as this school building is too good a one to permit to be damaged by filthy sewage backing into the basement. It is not necessary for me to go into detail but you can readily realize, the inconvenience to the Sisters and the unsanitary condition which eventually would be a menace to the health of the school children. I would, therefore, recommend, that action be taken at the earliest possible date, so that the work may be completed before school opens up in September.

(OVER)
(J. E. Morris,)
Acting Inspector,
Quebec and Maritimes.

Mr. E. Arsenault, Ind. Agent,
Restigouche, P.E.

Dear Sir,

I dread to see the winter months coming for our Mission Board, and Dundy pupils, who have such a long distance to face the bitter cold winter storms. Presently the class rooms are full to their capacity daily and it is so encouraging to see how well the pupils do learn when they attend school regularly. Of course some do play truant, but we must be sincere with them, and admit that during the winter months pupils miss, for the most part, due to the impossibility of standing the severe cold climate of the place.

Would it not be possible for you, Mr. Arsenault, to explore this...
Let to the Honorable Department of Indian Affairs, and if you explain things the way they really exist, I am positive that this favour will be granted them. I would not ask if I were to excuse me for my suggestion for pupils 3/4 of a mile from school, and then would be in need of looking for big boys over 12 years of age, as they are sturdy enough to overcome storms. But I would insist upon the necessity of having a sleigh covered with a heavy canvas, to haul the 23 youngest and farthest pupils of Millers Brook and Sandy Road during Dec., Jan. and Feb.

I'm forwarding you the names of the farthest families with the number of pupils of school age so that you may see for yourself that my demand is legitimate.

Many thanks!

Sister M. of the Holy Eucharist,
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa, Ont.

Enclosed please find letter from Sister M. of the Holy Eucharist, Principal of the Restigouche Indian Day School which is self explanatory.

I am fully aware of this fact and admit that absenteeism from school by the children stated on Rev. Sister's list, is due to the distance they have to travel this distance is approximately 1½ mile one way which means 3 miles per day for children of 7 and 8 years of age is no doubt too much to walk in cold and stormy weather.

I highly recommend transportation for the Months of December, January and February. If the Department approves this demand, I would suggest that we ask for Tenders amongst Indians who have horses and sleighs, from my opinion transportation may amount from $40.00 to $50.00 per Month.

Kindly give this matter your immediate attention.

(E. Arsenault)
Indian agent.
Ottawa, September 23rd, 1947.

Mr. L. Arsenault, Indian Agent,
Restigouche, Que.

We have your letter of the 13th instant with reference to driving some of the children to the Restigouche School.

It has been generally agreed by the officials of the various Departments of Education throughout Canada that children of ten years of age and under can walk two miles each way to school. Over ten years of age it is agreed that children can walk three miles each way to school.

We note that the children mentioned in your letter have only a mile and a half to walk each way. We are not prepared to provide transportation at Restigouche.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Sewer Restigouche Indian Day School,  
Restigouche, Bon. Que.

With reference to the above and further to previous correspondence I wish to report that this matter was further investigated and enquiries made with respect to the digging and refilling of ditch also as to the place of passage.

Upon examination of ground on which we intended to pass ditch at first, it has been found that it would be more advantageous to change our course and for the following reasons:

The matter of digging was discussed with Mr. J.E. Gendron, Supervisor for Quebec Agencies and a conclusion was reached that it would cost much more having the digging done by hand than by a Back-Digger which is available in the vicinity. Two hard surface roads would have to be crossed, Mr. J. English engineer would have to be on the spot to supervise the level and by having this hand dugged this would mean weeks for Mr. English at $1.25 per hour, whereas by digging with a back-digger, Mr. English could supervise the level, laying out pipes at the same time and would be a matter of days.

The new course we have found would decrease the length of about seventy (70) feet, would prevent us to less damage to private property and the lifting of fences, giving a better slant and same accommodation for future necessity.

The original estimates being $1,200.00 on which $566.00 already spent for purchase of pipes; balance $634.00
Re: Sewer Restigouche Indian Day School

Now the length of sewer to be dugged would be approximately 850 feet, digging and refilling by back-digger would cost $1.10 per foot, being $935.00 J. English, services approximately $125.00, man holes approximately $75.00.

This means that this whole expenditure would cost approximately $1,700.00 instead of $1,200.00 as previously stated. A further amount of $500.00 besides the amount of $1,200.00 already approved, would be required in order to execute this project. If the Dept. insist that the digging be done by hand, I cannot guarantee that the cost would average less than $1.00 per foot and as stated above Mr. English's services would cost much more owing to the fact that more time would be taken for the job.

Kindly advise the writer as soon as possible as to the decision and intentions of the Dept.

(E. Arsenault) Bupt.
Restigouche Indian Agency.

On June 9th while on my inspection trip at Restigouche, P.Q., the Indian Superintendent there asked me if it would be possible to have the above School wired and put in a temporary plant to light the School. I may add that I interviewed the Provincial authorities in regard to bringing electricity from Matapedia to Restigouche, and I was told that this demand should be made directly to the Cie Electrique du Bas St. Laurent. It is, therefore, my intention to have this Company supply us with electricity at Restigouche. I doubt very much though that we will succeed in getting it this year.

The Sister Superior at that School also requested a toilet for upstairs in their residential part of the School, and some repairs to their storage room in the cellar. Naturally, I pointed out to them that I had no authority to have these repairs made, but that I would refer the matter to your Branch and if you found it advisable, you would send one of your representatives to inspect this School during the Summer in order to ascertain if the improvements would be made, or not.

J. E. Gendron,

With reference to your telegrams of July 9th and 13th, we wish to confirm the following telegram sent to you today:

Dear Sir,

For the last three years the Principal of the Restigouche Indian Day School has asked different members of the Honourable Staff of Indian Affairs on visits to the school, to have a new fence around the teachers' residence and school yard. Each time the request was noted down as legitimate but to no effect. This year the wire is broken, the posts are rotten and the horses and cows have free access in the garden, lawn and flowers making it impossible for us to keep the grounds tidy and safe.

Would you kindly permit to our Indian Agent the authorization of having the work done this Fall? The expenditure cannot exceed $300.00.

Reference accounts from Sharp's Garage and Machine Shop, when I took over the administration of this agency on October 16, 1947, the Belco Plant (motor only) had been sent to the above mentioned garage for repairs, and Mr. Arnold advised Mr. J. H. Gedron and myself to that effect, and I was a new man coming in. Naturally thought that this work had been authorized and accepted this as being alright. I called at Sharp's Garage two or three times when in Campbellton on other business and made inquiries as to when the motor would be ready; most times when I would phone, and also I called in person, I was told that they were waiting for parts, and due to the fact that this type of machine was made in the U.S.A., parts were very difficult to get.

On November 24th, they brought the motor back and set it up in the basement of the agency office, naturally by this time the batteries were down and the men required to get the machine running properly etc., however the motor did not run as it should and they were advised, their man was again over, and from what I could see he busted himself with the coil for the day.

The motor continued to work badly, that is it would run for fifteen or twenty minutes at regular speed and would then slow down to the point where the meter would stop discharging and we would then have to shut it off. On December 3rd, I received this bill for $631.52 (amount according to figures shown by $42.52). On December 11th, this charge arrived while I was at dinner and asked me to come and open the office as he was a new coil for the motor (this could be put in a vest pocket without any trouble), etc., in spite of the fact that the small boat was crossing pedestrian traffic, he came around by truck (the other man driving) I told him that he had better return to Campbellton as I would have nothing further to do with the motor until the Department had been advised.

The engine is now here but is not being used, and I have not contacted Mr. Sharp in regard to this bill.
To my knowledge the only time that a 4 ton would have been needed would have been to take the engine to Campbellton and return it to this office.

This type of machine when new is worth about $300.00 and you will readily see by looking over this statement, that it is nothing short of robbery to submit a bill of this kind.

What has been said in regards to Voucher 1027, is also true of 1028 especially items marked Truck rental.

If further information is required you might ask Mr. J. H. Gendron, Regional Supervisor of Indian agencies for the Province of Quebec.

Awaiting your instructions and comments.

(Sgd) C. H. Nadeau, Sect.,
Restigouche Indian agency.

Dear Sir,

On Mr. Gendron's last visit he noticed that the old shabby Convent of 47 years' existence was falling to pieces. The old Convent belonged in 1902 to the Reverend Capuchin Fathers and in 1937 it was handed over to the Sisters in charge of the Restigouche Indian Day School and we have been using same for storage and wood shed. Dear Sir,

On my letter of March 23rd, I, the Principal of the Restigouche Indian Day School, asked the Honorable Department of Indian Affairs if I could open a new classroom for the newcomers or refuse them this spring due to lack of space. It was advised to delay the admittance of all the Indian pupils of 7 years of age till September and that Mr. A.W. Doucet would interview the matter as to what could be done. I see that Mr. Doucet did visit part of our province but returned to Ottawa before coming to see the school attendance and the overcrowded classrooms. I am told that our devoted Inspector will return in the fall to decide what should be done.

Since all the teaching staffs of our Convent schools are being definitely named in July, I will have to discuss the present situation by letter. I already spoke to Mrs. J. Gendron, Inspector of Agencies, of what could be done for September since I am informed that the enlargement of the school will take place only in the summer of 1950.

Reverend Father Lucien, Parish Priest of Restigouche benevolently offers us one classroom in the French school 100 feet away from the Indian School. Reverend Father intended to open a mixing room for that class for the White Mothers, but seeing our difficulty in lodging the 181 Indian pupils in the present school he would rent it to the Honorable Department of Indian Affairs for one year, at $30.00 a month. The said apartment can accommodate thirty pupils and is all equipped with the necessary desks and blackboards. Six cords of 128 cu. ft. of 16 inch wood would be needed for the classroom stove.
Mr. J. Gendron and Mr. C. R. Nadeau visited the five Indian classes and the French apartment above mentioned and can give to the Honorable Staff of Indian Affairs all the informations which I have failed to give.

I would highly appreciate knowing in the nearest future possible your final decision on this subject as I have to ask my Superior General in June the number of teachers necessary for the Restigouche Indian Day School.

Very truly yours,

Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist...
Principal

Dear Mr. Doucet,

I know that the new construction for the Restigouche Indian pupils will only be started in the summer of 1950, but the plans are made beforehand and as I might not be here then, I think it better for you and us to expose my ideas and fears to you on this subject.

Mr. J. Gendron said in between the lines, that it was not the Department's intention to build a new wing to the present 12 year old school but intended to make an entirely new school for boys where manual training could be taught. I highly appreciate such determination. Then, I also understood, that the boys would have men teachers. This absolutely lies in the Honorable Staff's power and choice. But, Mr. Doucet, we are just out of a similar experience made in Gaspé by men professors and I dread it in this case also. In Gaspé, the building had been made to provide for boys; but after two years experience the whole was handed back to the Sisters to the satisfaction of His Excellency Bishop LeBlanc and the population. Here, kind Mr. Doucet, the pupils have to be trained for choir singing, mass, funeral and wedding services, besides the regular course. If men professors are devoted enough to answer to those needs, we would put up no objection and we would be glad to keep only the girls. But if those professors do but their teaching and off they go, do you see the difficulties we would be
in, to control those boys who would be our pupils any more? Presently we can affirm frankly that the big boys are studious, obedient and can easily be controlled. In a word they give us no trouble. Why not simply have a manual training teacher and leave the boys under our direction?

You may say: "It is possible to find men teachers who will be ready to devote themselves for the good cause of Indian boys. Hope you say right but the Mr. A.J. Doucet of old are scarce now-a-days... I know you personally did it, and I hold from sound sources that you accomplished similar apostolate for many years, but you are one out of a hundred and will we fall on the right one?"

What I foresee is that after a few years the whole will be handed back to us, and if the new construction is made far from the present Indian Day School please do not forget the inconveniences.

I do not speak for me personally as I said, for I do not intend to be here next year, but I want to leave you my most humble opinion on the matter knowing that you will consider it wisely before final decision.

Very truly yours,

Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist,

We have received quotations re the new furnace for the Restigouche school. I am afraid these two gentlemen overlooked the real need of the school. As it is constituted at present there is no electricity and although we intend to have the school wired and put in an electrical plant, this is liable to take some time and the heating will be required shortly. Hence we will have to forget the idea of forced air circulation.

We wish to replace the present furnace by a coal burning furnace of sufficient capacity to heat the school under present conditions. We wish to have a unit to which a fan may be added when electricity is available. Please make sure that the furnace quoted on by Bradley and by English come up to this requirement. Kindly give this your earliest attention as we wish to proceed with the installation at the earliest possible date.

Dear Sir,

On Mr. A.J. Doucet's last visit to the Redgrouse Indian Reserve, the principal of the Redgrouse Indian Day School discussed once again the problem of the overcrowded classrooms and he has asked Mr. Doucet if the young Indian pupils of school age should be refused in September or if a new classroom would be opened either in the French school or elsewhere. Our inspectors asked if the Manual Training Room could not be fitted for that purpose, and stated, "Accommodation must be provided for all Indian pupils of school age." This made me understand that a new class would be opened.
for the said accommodation, and I have advised our Superior General of this fact so as to retain seven teachers for the Redpath Indian Day School. I have forwarded on July 27th to the Honorable Department of Indian Affairs the seven names of the teaching staff and requested, in the meantime, the seven application forms for the year 1869-70. I am in receipt today of six forms only. Does this mean that the Honorable Department refuses the opening of the new class or was it simply a secretary's error. I can easily copy a seventh form but what I am eager to know is your final decision on the matter.

I am presently making my retreat at the Mother House at Penobscot and will be leaving on the 15th of this month for Portland Maine. It will thus be useless to notify me. I would highly appreciate your advising Reverend Mother Mary of S. Rose, Superior General of your present necessity, as the missionary Sisters will soon be leaving for their respective missions.
Thrusting to hear from you, kind Mr. Neary, in the nearest future possible.

Very truly yours,

Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist.
TEARING DOWN OF THE OLD BUILDING AT THE RESTIGOUCHE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL - $600.00

a) Tearing down the old building all finished in plaster work inside.

b) Cleaning the grounds ready for the new construction. This means paying trucks at $3.00 an hour for transporting the old plaster, laths and rotten wood to the river.

c) The longest boards which can be saved between the openings of six doors and sixteen windows are 3½ feet in length on the outside walls only. These aborts boards cannot be easily used in the construction of the new store house and shed being the scantlings two feet apart. I might be able to use some in the roof.

d) The only useful building material which can serve in the new building would be 75 pieces of rough scantling for frames. Thus I could tear down the old building for $600.00.

e) Most of the 18 window frames are rotten and the glass panes are broken.

Alfred Beaulieu, Carpenter.

A request has been received from the principal of the Restigouche Indian Day School for a $200.00 grant for the Restigouche Homemakers' Club for the fiscal year 1949-50.

In fact, I might state the Restigouche Homemakers' Club is the only club in Canada which has been receiving assistance of this nature. MEMORANDUM

Dr. H.W. McGill

RE: RESTIGOUCHE AGENCY

I beg to submit a report of my inspection of the above Agency, made during the last part of June.

SCHOOL:

On June 19th, I visited the Indian Day School and found 130 children present, out of 174 registrations during the current school year. Children were neatly dressed and clean; the class rooms as well as other rooms were spotless.

I took much interest in looking over the exhibit of pupils' work and handicrafts. The amount of constructive work on the part of the sister in charge; sewing, knitting, etc., done by the girls show that the teaching of the sisters was not fruitless; amongst the collection I found, baby, child and grown-ups shirts, pants, dresses and windbreakers, all cut and sewn by the girls; girls' winter coats made from the materials authorized by the Department were most useful and the best practical mean to teach the girls how to make up their own clothing later on; boys' shirts and pants, all made at the school, were to be seen on many of the boys' persons, and all made up at a much lower cost than it could be purchased ready-made.

The idea of supplying the material to be made up by the pupils is most practical, providing we have such an interested person to supervise and direct the children, as Sister Mary of the Eucharist, actually in charge.

The boys have made many practical and useful articles, such as chairs and tables, plain, but solid; other fancy things were also made by the boys.

The pupils also took an interest in Red Cross work in its war effort; fine woolen knitted articles were made from the wool supplied by the Red Cross Society.

Upon my recommendation last year, the amount of twenty-five dollars was allowed for a school garden, and it was a pleasure to see the success achieved so far; the sister told me how the older boys and girls were pleased when garden work began this year; every one has a task to accomplish; the work is arranged around, weeding, cultivating, watering; at the centre of the garden, a large molasses punchpan is sunk half in the ground and kept filled, so that water is at the proper temperature at watering time, rather than using cold water from the well.

The following requests were made by the sister in charge:

Repairs to the sewing machine not to exceed five dollars.

Ten(10) single desks No.4 for the young ones (actually, many have to sit three on a desk for two)

I recommend that the above requests be granted, providing funds permit.

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Quebec Inspectorate.

RE: RESTIGOUCHE AGENCY.

I beg to report on my visit to the above agency during last month.

SCHOOL

The school garden started this year, has proven successful; it is hoped that the interest shown by the boys and girls will be kept up at home when they leave school. Dear Sir,

The teaching staff of the Restigouche Indian Day School is deeply touched by the congratulations made by the Honourable Staff of Indian Affairs, for the humble handiwork concocted here at school. As you stated, our aim is to develop a spirit of initiative, indispensable for a happy and proper living.

We are pleased to present to you, kind Mr. Doucet, the methods we are using in treating the discarded military socks.

1. Disinfect the socks with formaldehyde, by hanging them on lines in a well closed room, placing the solution in an empty tomato can, setting the latter on a coal oil lamp, till the disinfectant is evaporated.

2. Wash the socks. Here the Reverend Fathers washed them with their mechanic washer. We could have distributed the socks and have them washed by the Indian mothers, but we feared that all would not have been returned. This explains why the Reverend Fathers benevolently asked to wash them in their stead.

3. Each child selects as many socks of a similar shade as she will need to knit the work assigned. Either mits, bonnets, socks or sweater.

4. In general, the feet are cut off, but the legs are unravelled, starting by the bottom. Care must be taken as the grey yarn will sometimes break. The white yarn at the top of the socks is the strongest.

5. For mits, bonnets and even socks. By means of a spinning wheel, we twist one ply of grey yarn with one ply of white, from the top of the unravelled socks. For a better quality, we twist one ply of very fine home spun warp yarn with either the white or grey unravelled yarn. This makes a yarn strong enough for sweaters or socks.

6. We can also twist the yarn by means of a distaff of 1/4 foot, which we are forwarding to the Honourable Department. Before twisting with that apparatus, the yarn needs to be balled into a doubled ply.
7. If two strands of the best white yarn is used, we can dye it green or any desired colours for girls' dresses.

8. The only difficulties encountered are the inevitable knots.

The process may appear long, but to my personal opinion, this work is a very practical one. Each Friday afternoon there is always a demand from an Indian woman to come and twist her already prepared yarn at school, while the four women of the sewing club are at work.

Heartfelt thanks for the appreciation you have so kindly made of the humble articles made at school.

Gratefully yours,

Sister M. of the Holy Eucharist.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

The new program of Manual Work introduced in our Indian Day Schools since the last four years had often given me apprehensions concerning the intellectual progress of our pupils.

Lately two Indian orphan girls who had left the Restigouche Indian Day School, with a married sister in Montreal returned for their summer vacation and brought their rank cards. Dear Sir,-

Would the Honourable Department of Indian Affairs benevolently grant for the Domestic Science and Women's sewing Clubs of the Restigouche Indian Day School the discarded military clothes asked on the Requisition for School Material forms?

Dear Sir,-

In reply to your letter of the 27th instant I do not quite understand if it is your intention to send only letters for sewing purposes, to the Restigouche Indian Day School; the discarded military clothes requested on the 16th, or if it is your intention to definitely quit forwarding the said clothing.

I was aware that the discarded military clothes was not given to the Honourable Department free of charge as late Dr. A. Richard once stated, "This last car load of military clothes arrived for the three reserves amounts to $700."

I admit that such manual teaching is costly and if it is the desire of the Honourable Staff of Indian Affairs to close the Indian Women's sewing Clubs I think I could slowly do so without arousing complains. The $200, benevolently granted for the purchase of yarn, lining and heavy material to match with the discarded military clothing, I have tried not to spend more than $20. each month so as to have enough for the season. In spite of my extreme care to remain in the limits of $20. a month, I surprise myself many a times to exceed the expenses in this is with the discarded military clothing. If the second hand clothes is cancelled what will make them work with? If it is your desire, I am ready to close the women's sewing clubs as soon as you express such a wish.

Ottawa, January 4, 1945.

Rev. Sister M. of the Holy Eucharist, Principal,
Restigouche Indian Day School, Restigouche, Quebec.

In reply to your letter of the 3rd instant, I wish to say that it is not our intention to discontinue the Indian Women's Sewing Club, as long as the women are making good use of the services available. I wish, however, to point out that in order that these services may be more appreciated a certain amount of sacrifice must be made by the Indians themselves. I wish to suggest here, that there might be a possibility of some members of the club bringing in their own sewing material or at least a part of it. I know that this has been done to some extent but I am wondering if it could not be increased.

The material which you require according to the samples sent in in your letter of December 16th is not available. The underwear have all been distributed. There is a possibility that we might be able to procure some later.

The shirts that have been sent in 1941 were not used but shirts that were unsatisfactory through shrinkage, etc. This material, of course, is not available. There is, however, a possibility that used shirts may be obtained at a later date.

We are making a check-up and if any of this material should be available, we will be pleased to forward some to you.
I do not know whether or not the Agent has anything left from our last shipment. If so, you may ask him to turn over to you what you find suitable.

As regards the yarn and lining for which $200.00 has already been granted, I wish to know how much more money you would require to finish this year's work. It is unnecessary to state that this amount should be kept at the minimum.

There is another plan that might interest you, which has been in use at several other centres. We require skirts and windbreakers in the three sizes; small, medium and large. If the members of your sewing club are willing to make these we will pay them providing the price is fair. These articles would be made from new material which would be furnished from this office. We will pay the members of the club in kind, that is, by means of household goods and not in cash. The reason for this is obvious.

Please let me know at your earliest convenience the cost of labour for the making of the skirts and the cost of labour for the making of the windbreakers. We will be able to decide then, if it will be worthwhile to have these articles made by the Restigouche sewing club.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Restigouche Indian Day School,

We are rather uncertain as to how to advise you in the matter. These biscuits are made and stocked at London, but the season is now so far advanced that it will be difficult for you to purchase and deliver a supply to us in Montreal in time to be forwarded by our scows to James Bay. However, if you wish to place the matter with us and will wire us on receipt of this letter, we will get into touch with the manufacture, or his agent, and do our best to get immediate delivery.

We understand the present price is about twelve cents per lb., and it will cost you for transportation from Montreal to Rupert another twelve cents per lb., on the gross weight.

If it is your intention to proceed in the matter, we would ask you to comply with our request and send us a wire, as this is the only way that delivery can be secured in time. Practically all of our own supplies are now lying at Parry in Northern Ontario ready for the breaking up of the ice.

Yours very truly,

REVILLON FRERES TRADING CO. LIMITED.

Gentlemen,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th instant, regarding the supplying of a quantity of hardtack biscuits for the Rupert's House Indian day school.

Rt. Reverend Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 17th instant, enclosing accounts in duplicate covering the amount paid the Hudson's Bay Company and Levillon firm for goods furnished on the teacher's order and for supplies for the use of the Rupert's House Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that a cheque for $243.96 is being sent you today, which covers payment to December 31, 1922. In connection with these accounts, I have to state that, owing to the delay and difficulty in obtaining proper vouchers, it is considered advisable to make other arrangements for the payment of sweeping and scrubbing and the cutting and splitting of firewood at this school. Therefore, instead of the teacher issuing orders to the above firms for goods in payment of this work, the Department will allow the sum of $20 per annum from the beginning of the present fiscal year, viz., the first of April, last, for the janitor's services, which will include sweeping, scrubbing and cleaning the school.

We will also allow an expenditure not to exceed $70 for the providing of fuel, as well as sawing and splitting the same. It may be necessary for the teacher to continue the issuing of orders in payment of any work performed for the above purpose, but this Department will only reimburse you to the amount mentioned, which, it is considered, should be ample to cover the cost of these services. You may settle with the firms who supply any goods and you will be reimbursed to the above extent. As rental is paid for the use of the building, it is considered that there should be no charge made for any material purchased for repairs, etc.

It is thought that the above arrangement would be the most satisfactory and overcome the difficulty and delay in the receipt of proper vouchers and accounts. I shall be pleased if you will inform the teacher accordingly.

I have the honour to be,

Your Lordship's obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Dear Sir,

Six small boxes each weighing around 50 lbs for the Indian Day school have been received for which thank you.

If you will permit me to make a suggestion, boxes of biscuits weighing 100 lbs each have been received in years past and are a whole lot more satisfactory and so a good deal further. In my opinion the children look a good deal better since the biscuit ration has been adopted as a permanent feature in connection with the school.

These small boxes will only be half as useful as they contain just half of what I expected i.e., 702 8 boxes weighing each 60 lbs or more.

It will be to the interest of the school in every way and the biscuit ration is now a recognised part of school routine to have the 100 lb. boxes sent instead of small boxes as not in that case weigh all told the equivalent of seven or eight 100 lb. boxes.

Thanking you for past favors and trusting that this will be received as a helpful suggestion with reference to the school.

I remain

Sincerely yours

(Rv.) C.C. Bissett

Dear Sir:

We beg to submit to you the following extracts from a letter received today from our Rupert Post:

"As a result of their storage in our cellar, we trust the goods will be no worse than when first landed. Amongst the balance of Mission goods stored away in our warehouse there are quite a few cases addressed to the Missions evidently sent by the Dept. of Indian Affairs, and their contents are marked off on the outside of c/s as "Sea Biscuits". We should like to consult you as to whether you think the Dept. of Indian Affairs would sanction your Agents' opening any or all of these cases and distributing their contents by way of relief to the Indians. As you are aware, no missionary is resident here this Winter, consequently these biscuits are lying unused in our Warehouse.

The Dept. of Indian Affairs may not know as yet that the Indians are finding very little indeed in the Bush to help to keep them alive this Winter. Flesh, fish and fowl are extremely scarce, and already there are quite a few feeling the pinch."

"If you think it desirable, under these circumstances, and if you think the Government Dept. would sanction it, would you kindly notify us of..."
Sir,-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st instant, with reference to the "Sea Biscuits" lying in your warehouse at Rupert Post. In reply I beg to say that you may instruct your manager at that point to distribute these to deserving Indians.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean.
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

SUMMARY OF BUILDING OPERATIONS

Rupert's House Day School,
June 15, 1930.

The expenditure herewith represented covers the partial rebuilding of
the Rupert's House Day School.

Compensation for labour has been in the nature of relief for the
Indians rather than actual wages. Being small, it provided the barest living
wants in the case of the large families.

The school was built in 1900. It can scarcely be wondered at that
the foundation was so rotten, resting as it has done on boggy land
for some thirty years.

As the entire under portion required renewing, the building was torn
down and moved to a higher and dryer location. In the course of
rebuilding a completely new foundation and sleepers were provided.
This entailed the cutting and hauling of some sixteen logs. The outer
siding was found to be badly weathered and warped, as well as rotten at
the base, so that it could not be painted without considerable waste of
paint, time and effort. Accordingly a great portion of this has had to
be supplied. This entailed some more logs which are still being converted
into boards by means of the pit-saw.

Some lumber has had to be taken from the old building which is being
used as the school.

The Mission has supplied the roofing.

Rupert's House, Que.,
April 12, 1938.

M. L. Tyner,
