Dear Dr. Tyner:

I commenced work on the Day School. It seemed a bit early, but there was no alternative. Living conditions came to such a pass for some of these Indians that something had to be done right away.

The canoe building are on the job and it looks that they will do a very good job.

I noted the P.S. in your letter to the effect that you did not see why the school need be moved. My reason for suggesting removal is as follows:

The present site is boggy and, to my mind, most unsuitable as school grounds. Attempts had been made to drain it, but the place was almost impassable all last summer. Examination of the foundation showed that it had rotted badly, doubtless owing to the dampness of the area. To repair the building and leave it on such a spot was, to my mind, a waste of time, money and effort.

The present seems most opportune for this useful work. Labour is cheap. Indians want the work. It is far better, I think, for them to accomplish something while they are being supported, and they will have to be supported somehow. They generally ask for work here rather than a handout, which is a very good thing.

Apart from the school work there seems to be nothing in sight here. I have heard nothing definite about the canoe building.

So I am proceeding with the school work according to plan.

Last year I believe you said that you would send up some biscuits for the school children. We did not receive them. If it is possible to get them, by all means do so. I know that some of these children sometimes come to school without breakfast. Most of them can't afford an extra little.

I enclose some Vital Statistics.

With all good wishes to you and yours,

Yours truly,

Dear Dr. Orford:

I have once or twice this winter experimented with a hot meal served to our school children, and am hoping to secure sufficient co-operation from the Dept. to make this a more or less permanent arrangement. Last year the school boys planted a few potatoes, and we used these plus a little meat, etc., I supplied. This year with some of the seed you so kindly sent I hope to grow a lot more, although I have to get everything done by hand as our plough was taken away for Moose.

If I could get a couple of dollars a week for a woman to cook the meals, plus some salt pork or other meat, and some vegetables, I could try it for a time. Some tin plates and spoons and a cook pot would also help. There is a cottage here we use as a dispensary and office, which should be perfect for the job. Also, if I were given some small vegetable seeds too we could in time provide most of our needs. Some fish might be bought in summer but Moose is out as our people do not get enough for their needs.

When Mr. Watt of the H. B. Company was in Ottawa he spoke to Mr. Hoey whom I understand gave some encouragement to the idea. You will not mind my saying that our Rupert's Indians are not as resourceful as some of the 'Beaver enthusiasts' make them out to be. Last year they received ten dollars less for their beaver than Moose Indians, and the cost of food here is just about three times that at Moose. We missed the biscuits usually supplied by the Dept., and if these could be sent again it would be a godsend. The Indians who remain in the village all winter get no beaver allowance and need what help we can give as the children definitely come to school hungry. In summer the bulk of the people have spent their credit by the end of June and are a hungry bunch too.

I shall be so grateful for any help you can give and to know your reaction to the suggestion of a meal served, say, at noon each day.

With cordial wishes,

Yours faithfully,

(sgd.) A. F. Marshall.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment a letter received by you from the Reverend A. H. Marshall, missionary, and teacher in charge of the Rupert's House Indian Day School.

The officials here are somewhat disposed to be a little more liberal in our allowances for noonday lunches at Indian day schools, despite the limited funds at our disposal. We are of the opinion that by serving a fairly substantial noonday lunch the attendance at a number of our schools might be greatly improved.

We are definitely opposed, however, to an allowance to an Indian woman or to any other person for the preparation of these meals. These meals should be simple and should be prepared by the senior pupils, under the direction of the teacher. If additional assistance is required, it should be secured on a voluntary basis. Surely the time has not arrived when we must provide education, medical care and relief to Indians and pay for the cooking of the meals as well. I cannot think of anything more demoralizing than a policy such as this, if adopted at Indian day schools.

It is exceedingly difficult for the officials here to determine what allowance should be made at a particular school. A great deal depends upon local conditions. If a garden is cultivated at or adjoining that school, the vegetables produced tend to keep down the cost of the noonday meal. You might, in cooperation with the teacher, outline for us what you would consider to be a simple noonday lunch, together with an estimate of the cost of this lunch. If you do this, I can assure you the request will be very carefully and very sympathetically reviewed.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dr. T. J. Orford,
Indian Agent,
Moose Factory,
via Moosonee, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Re: Rupert's House Day School; Midday lunches;
Your letter of April 16th, file 72-2-5

Potatoes for seed purposes were sent to Mr. Marshall last fall. Attached is a requisition for other seeds which I believe he can quite easily cultivate near the school.

It may be possible to obtain ducks, geese and fish and also some beaver meat for the meat part of the meal and I will discuss this with Mr. Marshall when I reach Rupert's House this summer. Dear Sir: Re: Desks, Rupert's House School

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 15th instant, in which you seek information in respect to the availability of desks for the marginally-noted school.

We have been informed by the Purchasing Branch that it is impossible, for the time being, to secure desks that may be necessary from time to time to match other desks already installed at a number of our schools. We have been informed also that it is impossible to secure desks with steel or metal fittings. It might be possible to secure a number of desks constructed wholly of wood.

I should like to learn from you just how urgently needed the desks are at Rupert's House. A few days ago I received a letter from God's Lake in which the Indian Agent sought permission to purchase the lumber necessary for the construction of 12 double desks at the God's Lake School. If similar permission were granted to you, or to Mr. Marshall, would it be possible to have desks constructed at Rupert's House or at Moose Factory? I am anxious to hear from you again in respect to this matter.

Sir,

In your letter No. 152659/5 of the 26th April last relative to the creation of a new Roman Catholic school-house in the Abenakis village you told me that, if the Indians would agree to vote out of their funds the money required for this building, the Department would provide for the salary of a second teacher.

Now the necessary sum has been voted, the plans and specifications of the school-house have been approved by the Department, the contractor is at work building the school-house and in all probability it will be ready for the opening of the classes this fall. Therefore, in order that there may be no delay, I believe that it is important that the Department should now take the necessary steps to secure the services of this second teacher.

The present teacher is the Rev. Sister Marie Josephine of the Community of Grey Nuns of the Cross, whose mother house is in Ottawa. She teaches excellently and is very much loved by the Indians and they will be very glad to have another Sister from that Community as second teacher.

I believe that in order to secure the services of a second teacher as competent as the first it will be necessary to pay her as high a salary.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, November 25, 1905.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the letter from Mr. Belcourt, Public School Inspector, recommending the appointment of a third teacher for the St. Francis Roman Catholic school, I beg to say that I visited this school in the end of August, last, and have no hesitation in saying that it is one of the best, if not the best, Indian school we have. It is conducted by the Grey Nuns, who have a convent on the reserve, with three teaching Sisters.

They are now in receipt of a grant of $550 a year, but the enrolment would hardly justify the employment of three teachers. Most of the instruction is in French, but Sister Wood, the Superior, teaches the English classes, including those who take the commercial course. She told me that she thought she should receive some remuneration, and I think the Department might recognize the good work done at this school by increasing the grant now allowed the teachers. It all goes into the same fund and it would be quite satisfactory to the Superior of the Convent if they got it in that way.

In a memorandum I prepared for the Accountant in connection with the school estimates, I suggested that, if possible, a larger salary grant should be provided for this school, and pointed out that the title of the Indians to the reserve at Pierreville and St. Francis is dependent on the maintenance of the Catholic mission there and that the only way it can be maintained is by supplying sufficient funds to carry it on.

Ottawa, December 12, 1906.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

In August, last, the Department secured employment in the Government Works at Sorel for Albert Wawanclet, an ex-pupil of the St. Francis school. Shortly after he commenced there Sister Woods, the Principal of the school, wrote me privately asking if the Department would assist this boy in qualifying himself for becoming a mechanical engineer by providing him with a course in the International Correspondence Schools.

I told the Sister that I thought it would be better to wait some time to see how the young man was progressing before urging this matter. She wrote me again on November 28, last, on his behalf, and I then communicated with Mr. Desbarats, Director of the Shipyard, asking him to be good enough to let me have a report on this boy. His reply is on file, and you will see from it that the foreman reports that he is a bright lad, very steady at his work, painstaking and obliging, but that he has no mechanical ideas, having absolutely no experience in that line of work but gives promise of doing well. Mr. Desbarats states that a Shop Practice course in the International Correspondence Schools would be an excellent thing for him, if he knows enough English to follow it and that the Department would be well advised in helping him to take such a course.

I sent a copy of Mr. Desbarat's report to Sister Woods and asked her to inform me whether he has sufficient knowledge of English to follow the course. She replies that he has and that, as he was so anxious to begin, his
brother signed the contract and paid the first installment but now he is laid up and threatened with hemorrhage of the lungs; consequently he will be unable to keep up the monthly payments. The shop practice course, five divisions, which Mr. Desbarats recommends he should take, will cost in the neighborhood of $80, payable by monthly installments of $5 each. As this boy appears to be ambitious to perfect himself in his trade and is apprenticed at the Works, I think the Department would be quite justified, if funds are available, in stretching a point to enable him to pursue his studies in the correspondence schools. It is admitted that this method of teaching is most beneficial to pupils who are anxious to learn as everything depends on their own exertions.

I would only recommend that the Department should pay the installments so long as he continues to work assiduously on the course, and I am sure that Mr. Desbarats, who appears to be interested in the boy's advancement, would not object to sending in reports from time to time, showing the progress made by him. The Department would be under no obligation to the Schools; it would merely provide the monthly installments so long as it was deemed advisable. It is so seldom that we have an Indian boy who shows sufficient energy to advance himself that I consider that the Department might fairly come to his assistance. Of course his present wages are hardly sufficient to pay his board, without providing him with clothing. They are only $3 per week, while good wholesome board costs $5.50 per week in Sorel, the balance having to be made up by his friends.

Memorandum

Mr. Scott,

I beg to report that on Thursday May 20th., while on the Abenakis reserve I made an examination of the Catholic school building which is erected on reserve land, the building also being the property of the band.

The school is a two story frame building erected on a stone foundation which is deficient in depth, the excavation for cellar being made some distance in from the wall, the earth being sustained by boards which it is intended to discard and build up a stone wall supporting the earth bank and also forming the walls of cellar and furnace-room.

The building is of rather light construction and owing to the distance the joists are set apart the floors are weak and allow considerable vibration. It is intended to strengthen these by placing additional joists between each pair now in position and also placing posts to further strengthen beams now supporting floors. For this purpose a grant has been made by the Council of the Abenakis band.

The school apart from the building is a good and successful one, under able management as evinced by the thorough and efficient work of the pupils which I had the pleasure of witnessing in a recent examination during my visit to this reserve, especially as they are compelled to hold their classes under very considerable difficulties, in badly arranged rooms.
one of the school rooms being an old laundry addition to the kitchen which has been adapted for class use and is not at all suitable for the purpose.

Effective results are not to be expected except under reasonably good conditions and to get the best results from the capable Principal and staff in charge there welllighted and ventilated class rooms are required.

To provide suitable school accommodation it will be necessary to erect an addition containing modern class rooms more strongly built and provided with heating and ventilation.

The cost of erecting a suitable addition having two class rooms on the ground floor and the same floor space in one large room on the floor above, built in a substantial way on concrete foundation will cost about Two Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($2,500.00).

I would recommend that providing the Department views favorably the school need for more suitable class rooms that the Bands grant of $500.00 for repairs should instead be expended on the new building and all conveniences for heating and ventilation provided in the new wing instead of expending the amount on walls and joists etc., in the old building. The necessary strengthening can then be made to the old foundation and joists by placing under them beams and posts; these obstructions would not then interfere with the furnace etc., providing these were arranged for in the new addition.

The cost of strengthening the old building in this way would be nominal in comparison with the system proposed.

Architect.

INDIAN GIRL IS LAUREATE IN MUSIC OF ST. JOSEPH'S COLLEGE, PIERREVILLE

Miss Aurora Wawanolet, the Abenaki girl who won the highest distinction in the recent examinations at the Dominion Institute, Quebec City, is receiving the highest praise and admiration from her friends, and her instructor, the Rev. Father Martin, of the Convent of St. Joseph of Pierreville, are delighted with her achievements. In addition to obtaining first prize and winning the title of laureate of the college, Miss Wawanolet has also received the gold medal for the district of Montreal.

Miss Wawanolet, although only sixteen years old, has had a brilliant musical career. The examiners were Prof. J. D. Desjardins, Mr. F. E. and Mr. E. L. Martin. The success of Miss Wawanolet is an excellent example of the good results of the work conducted by the tribe, made possible by the Laurier Government. The amount of money given by the Indian Department contributed $2,000 to wards enlarging their little convent where the young members of the tribe receive culture and practical instruction that will enable them to do credit to their race and to their native land. The Rev. Sister Woods, the superressor of the convent, and the entire community is to be congratulated on the success of her efforts.

NOTES

Le Collège Saint-Joseph fut fondé en 1848 par Messire G. Gagnon, curé de Berthier, qui en confia la direction aux Clercs de Saint-Viateur. Reconstruit en 1885, considérablement agrandi en 1907, cet établissement commercial comptera bientôt parmi les plus importants de la province, grâce à une construction nouvelle qui en doublera la valeur. Cette annexe sera terminée dans le cours de la présente année scolaire.

Le Collège Saint-Joseph réunit toutes les conditions de confort et de salubrité qu'exige l'hygiène scolaire. Il a l'avantage d'être en communication facile avec tous les points des districts de Montréal et de Québec.

Le programme d'études comprend le Cours primaire et le Cours commercial. Après la sixième année, l'enfant possède une instruction primaire complète et se trouve en état de commencer les études commerciales ou classiques.

Le Cours commercial se divise en trois classes : Commerce, première année, — Commerce, seconde année, — Commerce, troisième année. Un diplôme est délivré aux élèves finissant qui subissent avec succès l'examen final.

La meilleure instruction ne vaut rien sans l'éducation. Au Collège Saint-Joseph, tous les efforts du maître tendent à inculquer à l'élève les principes catholiques et l'esprit d'initiative qui en feront un homme utile à sa famille et à la société.

OBSERVATIONS IMPORTANTES

Un prêtre est attaché à l'établissement en qualité d'animé.

La correspondance des élèves est soumise au contrôle du Directeur.

Au commencement de chaque mois, les parents reçoivent un bulletin qui les renseigne sur le travail, la conduite et les progrès de leurs enfants.

Les jours de parlour sont les mardis et jeudis après-midi, ainsi que les dimanches avant et après vêpres.

Le linge lavé au Collège doit être marqué au nom de l'élève. Nous ne sommes pas responsables des objets perdus.

Tout dommage causé à la propriété du Collège est à la charge des parents.

L'uniforme pour les fêtes et les dimanches est un habit noir. Nulle forme particulière n'est prescrite.

Les élèves venant d'un autre établissement doivent fournir un certificat de bonne conduite.

Les pensionnaires doivent apporter les objets suivants : serviettes, brosses, cirage, savon, miroir et peignes.

Les élèves, se mettant au cheur, doivent avoir une soutane et un surplus. Le Collège en lève moyennant 75 sous par année.

There are two or three families whose mothers are Abenakis but not the fathers, who live in the Abenaki village, and their children attend St. Joseph Academy. Such a state of things has always been tolerated in the past years and the children have always enjoyed the benefit of the high education given here by our good sisters the Grey Nuns. This year, I am told, they talk of putting those children out of the Academy or at least to make them pay.

expulsion of those dear children. As for me, I understand that it is an act of charity to receive these children and to instruct them, and I can assure you that I have witnessed several times the effect of the good example they gave to the Abenaki children by their intelligent work, their application and their success.

These children belong to very poor parents who earn their living here by making baskets, so that they have not the means of giving a cent for their instruction. If they are not allowed to come to the Academy, they will run in the roads and will be lost morally. It would be too bad, while there is room for them in the convent as in the past years.

And if the tribe allow these families here, it should allow the children to the Academy.

Knowing your spirit of justice and the interest that you bear us, I have confidence that you will treat this affair according to our wish and we will follow the direction that you will give us.

MASSON ACADEMY
DANVILLE—CANADA
PROSPECTUS

The Masson Academy, in Danville, Que., is under the direction of the Brothers of the Sacred Heart. Founded in 1906, this institution had been up to (1915) only a day school for boys. To comply with the wishes of many families, the school trustees of the town have built an important addition to the school house so as to enable the Brothers to admit boarders.

With respect to comfort, the Masson Academy is second to none of the other institutions of its kind; the rooms are spacious, well ventilated, lighted by electricity and heated by hot water. An extensive play-ground affords space to the boys for all kinds of games and in winter may be turned into a skating rink.

The Academy is beautifully situated, and Danville is well known as a health resort. The Grand Trunk station is at a short distance, five minutes walk.

Tuition

At the request of a good many English-speaking families in Danville and the neighborhood, the Academy has a double course of studies: 1st the French course, in which English has its due share; 2nd the English course, in which the French language is taught.

A commercial diploma is awarded to the student who successfully passes the annual examination made for that purpose.

Terms

Board and Tuition per month
Rent of bed and bedding per year
Rent of bed (spring bed and mattress) and wash-stand per year
Washing per year
Typewriting (optional) per month
Telegraphy per month

Payments should be made in advance every month.

No reduction will be made for an absence of less than fifteen consecutive days.

An extra of $1.50 is charged at the beginning of each year for the use of the library and table set.

Parents may deposit with the Director a sum of money to defray the incidental expenses of their children.

In case of illness of their children, parents will be charged extra for the medicines and doctor's fees.

Parents are charged extra for books and other stationary articles which may be procured at the Academy.

Bed spring-bed and mattress are furnished by the Academy.

Besides books each boy should be provided with about three sets of light underwear, as many of heavy underwear, two night gowns, two suits, an overcoat, a pair of overshoes, some towels, scarf, a looking glass, a comb, shoe and clothes brushes, napkins and a bag for laundry.

Though the students do not wear any particular uniform, parents are requested to provide their children with a black or navy-blue suit and also with a common blue cap.
ACADÉMIE MASSON
DANVILLE, P. Q. CANADA
PROSPECTUS

L'Académie Masson, à Danville, est dirigée par les Frères du Sacré-Coeur. Fondé en 1906, cet établissement a été jusqu'à cette année, 1915, qu'un simple externat répondant aux désirs d'un grand nombre de familles, dans les années qui ont le contrôle de l'école, ont une annexe considérable à l'externat afin de permettre à Frères de recevoir des élèves pensionnaires.

Dans le rapport du confort, l'Académie Masson ne le fait pas seulement aux autres institutions similaires ; ses appartements sont vastes, bien ventilés, éclairés à la lumière électrique et chauffés par des fourneaux à eau chaude. Le grand cours de récréation permet aux élèves de faire leurs jeux, ébats, en été dans d'intéressantes parties de balle au champ, en hiver sur un grand patinoir.

Le site de la maison est des plus beaux, et la salubrité de Danville est proverbiale. La gare du Grand Tronc n'est qu'à cinq minutes de l'Académie Masson.

Enseignement

Pour faire droit à la demande d'un grand nombre de familles anglaises et irlandaises habitant Danville ou les environs, l'Académie Masson a deux cours d'études : le cours français ou la langue anglaise à sa bonne part ; le cours anglais où le français entre comme spécialité. Un diplôme commercial est accordé à tout élève qui réussit avec succès l'examen qui a lieu chaque année à cet effet.

Conditions

Instruction et pension... par mois .................. $12.00
Lit complet ........................................... $10.00
Lit (matelas et sommier) et lavabo par année .... $5.00
Blanchissage ........................................... $10.00
Chavigraphie (facultatif) ... par mois .............. .50
Télégraphie ............................................. .50

Les paiements se font d'avance tous les mois.

Aucune déduction n'est faite à moins d'une absence de quinze jours consécutifs.

Au commencement de l'année scolaire, chaque élève doit payer $1.50 pour l'usage de la bibliothèque et le service de table.

Les parents peuvent déposer chez le Frère Directeur un petit montant d'argent pour subvenir aux dépenses accidentelles de leurs enfants.

En cas de maladie, les honoraires du médecin et le prix des remèdes sont à la charge des parents.

Les élèves peuvent se procurer à l'Académie les livres et autres fournitures classiques.

Le lit et les matelas sont fournis par la maison.

Outre les livres et les habits, les parents doivent fournir à leurs enfants des serviettes, des robes de nuit, du savon, un peigne et un miroir, du cirage, une brosse pour habits, des brosses pour souliers, des serviettes de table et un sac à linge.

L'Académie Masson n'a pas de costume particulier ; toutefois les parents sont priés de fournir à leurs enfants, pour les dimanches, un complet noir ou bleu foncé ainsi qu'une casquette ordinaire de cette dernière couleur.
Extrait de Règlement

Les élèves sont reçus en tout temps ; cependant il est grandement désirable que les parents les envoient au début de l'année scolaire.

Les enfants qui n'ont pas leur père ou leur mère à Danville ne sont reçus qu'à titre de pensionnaires.

Toutes les lettres et tous les paquets sont reçus et envoyés par le Directeur.

Les pensionnaires ne peuvent sortir en ville qu'accompagnés de leurs parents les jours de congé seulement.

Les enfants de croyance différente admis à l'Académie Masson, sont tenus de suivre le règlement de la maison.

MEMORANDUM.

The Schools Branch,

While last visiting the Abenakis Reserve and the school situated there the Superior of that school requested me to obtain for her the following articles, which she claims are absolutely necessary. The reason that this request is made to the Department through me is that the Agent resides several miles away from the reserve and it is very difficult to communicate with him.

The things which the Superior asked for are as follows:

Two light ladders for putting on the double windows, costing about $9.00 each.

Posts, pulleys and wires for hanging clothes, costing $16.00.

Partition in basement under old building to provide a vegetable cellar. Cost estimated at $40.00.

Two days' work for one man to empty and clean the heating system in the spring and fall. Cost $5.00 each time.

Fencing of the school lot on the east side between the Government property and Mr. Papineau's. Cost estimated at $50.00.

Taking off two wall radiators in the basement and installing same in two of the bedrooms on the first floor, with the necessary connections and piping. Cost $80.00, including work and materials.

One typewriter to replace an old one, which cannot be repaired, also the repairing of another which is in a damaged condition.

Renewing of fifteen blinds.

Painting of the exterior of the whole building.

Authority to purchase yearly five tons of chestnut coal instead of a like amount of furnace coal which is now being supplied.

Upon hearing the explanation given by the Superior I beg to recommend that the above articles and work be granted, with the exception of the painting, which can be done better early next spring by contract.

Dear doctor McGill,

Living near Odanak, I cannot avoid being approached by interested parties as well as taking an interest in the work and life of the Indian mission, and so it is that the Superior of the Grey Nuns' Order, through her friends and admirers, confided to me the present request.

The term of Sister Marie-Josephine, as Superior of the convent, expires in two years only. She will have to carry on and remain where she is for that additional period of time although her salary as teacher is to be discontinued on account of having attained the age of sixty-five. This would cause duplication as another teacher would have to be brought in and at cost to the administration of the convent.

With her health and faculties well preserved, Sister Marie-Josephine still remains the heart and soul of the institution she has founded, and if it were at all possible to grant an extension of her term as teacher, it would not only mean economy but it would certainly be received with gratitude as a testimony of appreciation to the fine lady who consecrated her whole life for the good of the Indians.

War Savings Certificate.

I have for acknowledgment War Savings Certificate No. X20135697 for $25.00, registered in the name of Arthur Guy Bill Luke, enclosed with your letter of January 7th, 1943. This Certificate will be taken care of for the time being.

The motive of the Indians to invest in War Savings Certificates, Victory bonds, etc., should be commended, but I am sorry to say we have not the proper facilities here for keeping such securities for Indians. Many Indians are in the position to look after their own securities just the same as the ordinary white person, but for those Indians who continually move from one place to another, I think it would be better to have their extra money deposited in the Indian Savings Accounts. This, as you know, is a good investment and the Treasury Office maintains a proper ledger account for each individual.

This information is given to you not for the purpose of discouraging in any way the War effort by the Indians, but rather to have them look after their own War Savings Certificates.

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Ottawa, January 14, 1943.

Dr. H.H. McGill

RE: Pierreville Indian Agency.

A local industry is giving work to a fair number of Indians, at a fair wage salary; some are also employed at war industries in Sorel, earning much higher salaries, however, due to the high cost of living accommodation in Sorel, or even bus travel between Pierreville and their work, those working locally are almost as well off, having no board nor travelling to pay.

It also appears very easy for some of our Indians to obtain liquor in Sorel, and bring it to the reserve for consumption and some suspected sales over the week end.

Since we have no constable on the Pierreville Reserve, the monthly patrol made by the R.C.M.P. from Trois-Rivières, is not sufficient to prevent the circulation of liquor on the Reserve, and unless drastic steps are taken, this matter will be getting worse and worse. The most efficient way to stop this would be to appoint a resident Indian constable who could act quickly. The fact that he lived on the Reserve would have some effect also, if it is only the fear to be caught with liquor.

The Sister Superior of our school has complained to the Agent that many children are allowed to stay out so late at night that they come to school next morning without doing their homework. If a local constable were appointed, he could very easily see that school children were home early at night and stayed there.

The services of patrols by the R.C.M.P. detachment from Trois-Rivières, may be more efficient in summertime as they can reach Pierreville within a couple of hours, but in winter there is only one train a day each way. Besides, matters such as liquor are harder to deal with and take longer to follow up; the R.C.M.P. cannot stay here day after day waiting, owing to their limited staff and so much other work to do.

This suggestion of an Indian constable could at least be tried for one year, as the cost is low, and the curse of liquor is so detrimental to our Indians. The fact that they are
now earning a living, should be no reason to let the liquor circulate more freely on the Reserve; they surely could put that extra money in to something far more useful to their families.

A local Indian could well attend to that matter; Dr. B. Maurault our Indian Agent is also of that opinion and thinks we could get a man for about $150.00 per year.

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Madam:

Your letter of September 4, addressed to the Prime Minister, has been passed on to this Branch for consideration and reply.

May I state that it is exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, to authorize the enrolment of children other than Indian children at an Indian day or residential school. The education of your children in the province of Quebec would appear to be a provincial responsibility and one that should be discussed with the school inspector for your district. The Dominion Government has no legal or constitutional authority to permit your children to attend the Indian school on the Odanak Reserve.

You state in your letter that there is a school one mile distant from your home and that a charge is made for instruction, in your case, at the rate of $12.50 per month. If you are a taxpayer in the district, it is difficult to understand why this charge should be imposed. However, this is a matter that lies wholly outside our jurisdiction and should be discussed with the local school authorities.

This is the second request we have received in one week from white citizens, asking permission for the enrolment of their children at the Odanak Indian Day School. You will readily understand that to grant these requests would establish a very dangerous precedent and one that would in all probability lead to endless administrative difficulties. You might show this letter to your school inspector.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

May I draw your attention to a fact which occurred in the Abenakis village of Odèsek, Quebec.

Sister Marie Joséphine, who during forty-four years was a missionary with the Abénakis was recalled to her community.

As I was born close to this village, and still spend my summers there, I often receive the visit of these Indians whom I advise to the best of my knowledge, and I may add without any false modesty, that I have done much for them in many ways.

The Abénakis are under the impression that this nun, who has brought up and educated them, and made good christian citizens of them for the past forty-four years, has been recalled due to an order from the Department.

Their affection for this Reverend sister whom they consider as a mother is remarkable, and they are grieved at her dismissal.

I am enclosing copy of a petition signed by everyone of them, and which has been forwarded to the mother house of the Community of the Grey Nuns, at Ottawa, and which is self explanatory.

Should this come under your jurisdiction, would it not be possible to reconsider the matter and grant to these Indians that which they request urgently.

I am not writing as a lawyer, but as their friend, and I am confident in your sense of justice and your great desire to help Indians morally and materially.

Very truly yours,

Edmond Courchesne.
We, the undersigned members of the Abenakis Mission of Odanak, deeply regret the departure of our Sister Superior, Rev. M. Joséphine. We note the change since Sister St-Gaetan has already taken over the duties of Superior of the Convent.

We abide by the decisions of the Council, and have no intention of interfering with the affairs of the Community, but we are very much interested in knowing the reasons which have motivated such a sudden change.

Rumour circulate here that the Indian Affairs Branch had something to do in the matter. It is said that Sister M. Joséphine was accused of having taken too much interest in our affairs, and criticized the acts of certain employees of the Department. It is quite easy to bring up an accusation, but care must be taken not to exaggerate. Sister M. Joséphine has always looked after our interests, as a mother naturally takes an interest in the welfare of her children. This is only logical, and we can see nothing our of the ordinary in that.

If the Abenakis have deemed it their duty to protest against certain acts of the Indian Affairs Branch, Sister Josephine had nothing to do with it; she did not initiate any hostile movement, as it is claimed in certain quarters.

Useless to remind here the deep devotion and zeal displayed by Sister M. Joséphine during the forty-four years she spent among the Abenakis. The entire mission acknowledge her merit. Half a century of devotion to religious life is an entire existence.

The matter deserves consideration.

As a practical conclusion to this petition, we humbly but firmly seek the return of Sister M. Joséphine, as Superior at Odanak, as soon as possible. We consider that this request is more of a "claim" than a "favor" requested, since we already
Received the definite promise of the Community that she would not be moved. Once again, we do not intend to dictate to the Community the decisions it should make, but when the details of this unfortunate incident are known to us, we shall be in a better position to discuss the matter.

We have the honor to be,

Respectfully ours,
The Abenakis of Odanak.
Montreal, 5 octobre 1944

I may state by way of comment that Indian day school teachers, whether they be members of a religious Order or lay teachers, retire under existing regulations at age 65. Sister Mary Josephine, having reached this age, a few years ago, was retired from our service in June, 1940. Sister Mary Josephine, however, although removed from our payroll at that time, appears to have remained on at the teasherege, acting in a kind of honorary capacity or as teacher emeritus. St-François, le 29 août 1946.

Monsieur le Président,

Sans doute vous êtes au courant de l'épidémie de Poliomyélite (paralysie infantile) qui sévit dans toute la province et aussi dans notre comté.

Présentement les cas dépistés et déclarés ne diminuent pas et à date nous en avons trouvé près de 25.

Etant donné que le temps le plus dangereux est du 15 août au 15 septembre, je vous conseille fortement, Monsieur le Président, de bien vouloir retarder l'entrée des classes au lundi le 16 septembre.

Plusieurs commissions reçoivent des élèves de l'extérieur ce qui pourrait augmenter le nombre des malades.

Si malgré le retardement dans l'ouverture des classes, il se découvre d'autres cas, personne n'aura de reproche à se faire.

La maladie est si grave et les suites si pénibles et tristes qu'il vaut la peine de prendre toutes les précautions nécessaires.

Vous remerciant de votre bonne coopération, je vous prie de croire à mon entier dévouement.

Docteur Réginald Bourgault,
Médecin-hygieniste.
Dear Sir:

I have received the enclosed circular addressed to all the schools and institutions in the county of Yamaska by the Hygienist Doctor, in respect to the disease (poliomyelitis) now existing in the Canada and United States.

I called the Doctor to know if there was any danger to open the reserve school in the beginning of September since there was no case reported on the reserve and that there was no outsiders attending this school. He answered me it would be much wiser to wait till the 16th.

According to request I have advised the Principal to wait till the 16th.

Hoping this action will be approved,

I remain,

Yours truly,

Dr Michel Tetresult,
Indian Agent.

N.B. There is no case of the above disease so far.

Dear Sir,

You have been very kind, as ever, to accept taking up the case of the children of my nephew, Gilbert Ali. Mr. Ali lives, since a week, in the Odanak Indian Reservation, right near the Indian School, and his children do not have the right to attend that school. They are unable to come to Pierreville on account of the distance and particularly because the Winter roads are practically not kept in the village of Odanak. Mr. Ali has not been able to find a place to rent in Pierreville and, if the Department of Indian Affairs refused to grant this permission, the children would be deprived of attending school this year.

Furthermore, I wish to point out that I am a distinguished benefactor of the Odanak Indian School. My sister who belongs to the Order of the Grey Nuns of the Cross, is a foundress of the school, and I gave much money to organize that school which had a humble beginning 50 years ago. It seems to me that the signal services which I rendered, since 50 years, to the Odanak school should dispose the authorities of the Dept. of Indian Affairs to grant the privilege which is requested.

Furthermore, Mr. Gilbert Ali is a veteran of the last war; he served two years in the Army.

Those are additional reasons which I could not give you over the telephone.

I am assured in advance, Sir, that with the help of a lawyer like yourself who always wins his cases with the government, my little nieces will soon be able to attend school. I am ready to pay the school charges for those children.

Respectfully yours,

Milton Rousseau,
Pierreville.

Dubois, Esq., M.P., Gentilly, Nicolet County, Quebec, in French, enclosing a letter from Milton Rousseau, Pierreville, Quebec, also in French, concerning permission for the children of his nephew, Gilbert Ali, residing on the Odanak Indian Reservation, to attend the Odanak Indian School. Also find enclosed English translation of both letters.

Please have a letter prepared for Mr. Pratt's signature, in French, to Mr. Dubois.

Leita Vail Allingham
Assistant Secretary.

Mr. Hoey:
For draft reply as requested.
Ottawa, 25 November 1946.

Dr. Michael Tetrault, Indian Agent,
PIERREVILLE, Quebec.

Attendance of White children at Odanak
Indian Day School

We have received a letter from L. Dubois, Esq., M.P., Nicolet County, P.Q., enclosing a letter from Milton Rousseau, Pierreville, requesting permission for the children of his nephew Gilbert Ali to attend the above school. The Department can grant such permission if there is room in the school and if the principal and Indian Agent concerned recommend such action.

Could you please report on this case?

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, 25 November, 1946.

Dear Mr. Dubois:

I have for answer your letter of November 17 with attached letter of November 7.

There are several places in Canada where white children have received authority to attend our Indian schools under circumstances similar to those pointed out in Mr. Rousseau's letter. This permission depends entirely on the accommodation available at the school concerned. The records of the Indian Affairs Branch show 40 children registered on the rolls of this school.

Therefore it will be necessary to refer this matter to the Indian Agent at Pierreville for his recommendation. As soon as an answer is received, I will advise you further.

Yours sincerely,

W.J.F. Pratt,
Private Secretary.

Lucien Dubois, Esq., M.P.,
Gentilly,
Nicolet County, Quebec.
Ottawa,
le 27 novembre 1946.

M. Lucien Dubois, député,
Gentilly (Nicolet)
Québec.

Cher monsieur Dubois,

On m'a prié de répondre à votre lettre du 17 novembre, à laquelle était jointe une lettre du 7 novembre.

Il existe plusieurs endroits au pays où les enfants des Blancs sont autorisés à fréquenter les écoles Indiennes parce que la situation où ils se trouvent est identique à celle mentionnée dans la lettre de M. Rousseau. Cette autorisation n'est accordée que là où il y a suffisamment d'espace pour loger les élèves. Les dossiers de la Division des affaires Indiennes indiquent que quarante enfants fréquentent cette école.

Il sera donc nécessaire de référer cette question à l'Agent des Indiens à Pierreville pour qu'il nous fasse ses recommandations. Dès que nous les aurons reçues nous vous écrirons de nouveau.

Bien à vous,

W.-J.-F. Pratt,
Secrétaire particulier.

le 27 novembre 1946.

Sierville, December 7, 1946.

Dear Sir,

Attendance of White children at Odanak Indian Day School

Answering your letter of the 28th of November 1946, I have secured information in regard to the admission of Mr. Gilbert Ally's children in the above Indian school.

The principal assures me there is room for these children and that she is ready to accept them. They are four of them: two boys 12 and 10 and two girls 13 and 6 years of age.

Personally I have no objection to the acceptance of these pupils in the Indian school, even though it may raise some protestation in the part of the white living on the Reserve, especially from those married to Indian girls to whom this favour has been refused these last years.

Will these children be accepted like Indian pupils or if they will have to pay? If so I would like to know the amount and who is going to collect.

Yours truly,

Dr. Michel Forget,
Indian Agent.
